900.00 GENERAL.
 
900.001 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Interpretation of Definitions. The terms defined in this chapter shall
have, throughout the Street and Sidewalk Area Code, the meanings stated. Where
words used herein are defined in other regulations (including the Public
Utility Code, Zoning Ordinance, and the Land Planning and Development
Regulations) they shall have the meaning as is therein defined. Where words are
not otherwise defined they shall carry their customary meanings as defined in
Webster's Standard Dictionary. Words used in the singular include the plural;
and the plural the singular. Words used in the present tense include the future
tense. The word "shall" is intended to be mandatory. The word "may" is
directive and to be complied with unless waived.
 
   (b)   General Definitions.
      "DEAD END STREET" means a street, or portion thereof, which is not a
through street; a street, or portion thereof, having only one intersection with
a through street; a street or series of streets upon which all traffic must
pass through one specific intersection in order to gain access to a higher
order street.
 
      "PEDESTRIAN WAY" means a path of travel limited to pedestrian traffic.
 
      "STREET" means: 1. Any path of vehicular travel serving more than four
(4) dwelling units, or more than two non-residential fee simple lots. 2. An
avenue, highway, road, thoroughfare, boulevard, parkway, alley or other way
proposed for vehicular traffic. 3. The land between the established or proposed
street right of way lines whether improved or unimproved, and may comprise
pavement, shoulders, gutters, sidewalks, division strips or other areas within
the street lines. 4. Any existing State, County, Township or Municipal street
or way shown upon a plat heretofore duly approved, filed and recorded in the
office of the Recorder.
 
      "THROUGH STREET" means a street, or portion thereof, between two
intersections and along which travel in both directions would provide access to
a higher order street, or streets, without passing through a common
intersection.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.002 CITATION.
   These regulations, rules and standards for public and private streets;
public and private sidewalks and other pedestrian ways; and other construction
or improvement work within dedicated street rights of way including the
planting and care of trees therein, and on other public lands; and further
including procedures to be followed in the application and administration of
these regulation, and the penalties for any violation thereof, shall be known,
cited and referred to as the Street and Sidewalk Area Code (codified as Title
One of this Part Nine - Streets, Utilities and Public Service Code).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.003 PURPOSE.
   The general purpose of these regulations shall be to guide and regulate the
planning, design, construction and maintenance of street and sidewalk areas,
and other improvements and resources as are provided for herein, in order to
protect the public health, safety, convenience, and general welfare of the
Municipality.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.004 OBJECTIVES.
   It is intended that the provisions of these regulations shall be to achieve
the following objectives.
   (a)   Provide an appropriate and accessible system of streets and sidewalks
in the community.
   (b)   Insure adequate and economical provisions for streets and sidewalks in
order to conserve the public funds.
   (c)   Provide for the development and expansion of the street and sidewalk
systems to support current service requirements and desirable community growth.
   (d)   Provide safe and convenient traffic circulation for both vehicular and
pedestrian traffic.
   (e)   Protect and preserve public facilities and improvements within public
rights of way, easements and other public land.
   (f)   Protect and preserve the natural beauty and resources of the Chardon
Forestry District (Ord. 1174; 08-11-88) and provide for the control,
supervision and maintenance thereof.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.005 VALIDITY.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or other phrase of these
regulations is, for any reason, held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be
invalid, such decision shall not effect the remaining portion of these
regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.006 CONFLICT.
   (a)   When a conflict arises herein between a general requirement and a
specific requirement, the specific requirements shall prevail.
 
   (b)   When a conflict arises between a requirement in these regulations and
a requirement in another regulation the resolution shall be in accordance with
the provisions of Sections
101.06 and
101.07 of the Municipal Administrative Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.007 COPIES OF REGULATIONS.
   The Municipality shall make available to developers copies of this Street
and Sidewalk Area Code and other adopted plans, regulations and information, as
are associated therewith, at a cost to be determined by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.008 REQUIREMENTS ARE MINIMUM.
   The improvements required by these regulations (including but not limited
to, streets and sidewalks) are herein deemed the minimum improvements necessary
in the public interest to provide. essential services and protect the public
health, safety and general welfare. Said improvements shall be provided and
installed by the developer, at his expense, in accordance with all applicable
Municipal requirements and regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.01 SCOPE OF REGULATION.
   The planning, design, construction and maintenance of streets, sidewalks and
other pedestrian ways, and other facilities and/or improvements within public
rights of way, easements and other public lands shall be in accordance with
these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
900.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   Except as otherwise provided for herein, the Public Service Director shall
be responsible for the administration and enforcement of the regulations
contained in this code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.12 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No work within the scope of the regulations contained herein shall commence
without first obtaining the necessary approvals and permits from the
Municipality and paying all required fees.
   (a)   Work permits shall be issued by the Authority having jurisdiction for
the regulation governing the work upon application and after all necessary
approvals have been granted.
   (b)   Proposed work which is an integral part of a development project which
is subject to a Site Development Permit, and which work shall be accomplished
at the time of initial construction of said project, shall not require a
separate work permit. However, said work shall conform with all other
requirements of this regulation and the regulations contained in this code.
   (c)   When, in the opinion of the Authority having jurisdiction, the
proposed work may be classified as a minor repair, and the proposed work will
be done in accordance with all other requirements of these regulations, the
permit requirement may be waived.
   (d)   Permit fees shall be as set forth in Section
900.18.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.13 PROJECT SUBMITTAL PROCEDURE; RECORD DRAWINGS.
   (a)   The submittal of proposed work or improvements within the scope of the
regulations contained herein shall be in accordance with the requirements of
the Land Planning and Development Regulations for the construction project of
which they are a part (see Chapter
1145 (Procedure)).
      (1)   When the proposed work is not an integral part of a larger project
then the submittal shall be in accordance with the requirements for single
building site development (see Lands and Improvements For Public Use; Section
1145.03 Project Classification).
      (2)   Drawings and specifications for the proposed work and/or
improvements shall be reviewed by, and shall subject to the approval of, the
Municipal Engineer and such other reviewing authorities as may be designated by
the Municipal Approving Authority for the subject project. The Municipal
Engineer's review and approval shall include, but is not necessarily limited
to, planning and design standards, required improvements, accepted engineering
practices and standards. Copies of all design calculations shall be submitted
for review by, and shall be subject to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer.
 
   (b)   Within sixty (60) days of the completion of construction of
improvements the developer shall furnish the Municipality a set of record "as
built" drawings of the improvements when so required by the regulations
contained herein. Said record drawings shall conform to the requirements of
Chapter
1151 (Submittal Content Requirements) and the Municipal Standards For Plan
Contents.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.14 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Authority having jurisdiction may adopt, subject to the approval of
Council, such rules and regulations as may be necessary and appropriate for the
effective administration and enforcement of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
Said rules and regulations shall have the same force and effect as ordinances
when not repugnant thereto or to State law.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.15 ANNUAL REVIEW OF REGULATIONS.
   The Authorities having jurisdiction for regulations herein shall review said
regulations on an annual basis. Said review shall include, but is not limited
to, insuring the continued validity of all regulations; insuring the absence of
conflicts within these regulations and in their relationship to other
regulations; and the development and proposal of such additional amendments as
are deemed necessary and appropriate.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.16 AMENDMENTS TO REGULATIONS.
   Amendments to these regulations may be initiated by the Authorities having
jurisdiction or Council. If initiated by an Authority having jurisdiction, then
they shall first be subject to review by such committees and/or consultants as
is required by policy of Council. Amendments shall be subject to such public
hearings as may be necessary to conform to applicable requirements of R.C. §
711.101. If the amendment is approved by Council then an amending ordinance may
be adopted by a majority vote thereof.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.17 VARIANCES.
   (a)   The Municipality may consider variances to certain Planning and Design
Standards set forth in the regulations of this Code. Variances to other
standards, requirements, procedures or regulations contained herein shall not
be considered. No variance to, and no modification of requirements to conform
with, any of the following standards and/or regulations shall be considered
unless specific provisions are otherwise noted in said standard or regulation.
      (1)   No "Municipal Standard Specification" shall be varied.
      (2)   No "minimum" planning and design standard shall be varied.
 
   (b)   Variance to this Code shall be regulated by, and in accordance with,
the provisions of this section, Section
900.91 and Section
1143.17 (Variances) and Chapter
1145 of the Land Planning and Development Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.18 SCHEDULE OF FEES.
   The fees associated with the administration and enforcement of the Street
and Sidewalk Area Code shall be as provided for herein, paid as prescribed
herein and in addition to any other fees required by other Municipal
regulations.
   (a)   Permit fees: Shall be paid at time of permit application submittal.
      (1)   Street opening work permit: one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
      (2)   Engineering review fee: three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00).
   (b)   Deposits: Shall be paid upon submittal of plans or request for
inspection and/or testing. The total final amount shall be the actual cost
incurred by the Municipality for administering and conducting the required
action (including, but not limited to reviews, inspections and testing). Any
balance remaining after final municipal approval shall be refunded by the
Municipality within sixty (60) days; any charges by the Municipality in excess
of the deposit shall be paid by applicant within thirty (30) days of receipt of
an invoice for the balance. No final Municipal approval for the project shall
be granted until all outstanding fees have been paid in full.
      (1)    The deposit for review of proposed street work which is within the
scope of the Land Planning and Development Regulations shall be an amount as
provided herein.
      (2)    The construction inspection deposit for street and sidewalk area
work which is within the scope of the Land Planning and Development Regulations
shall be equal to ten (10%) percent of the estimated total cost of construction
(not including "prevailing wage") for all improvements requiring inspection
services.
      (3)    The work and materials testing deposit shall be one hundred (100%)
percent of the estimated cost of materials testing, plus testing of work
during, or after, construction, plus any acceptance tests or procedures
required for improvements to be dedicated to public use.
      (4)    The cost for inspections of street and sidewalk area work for a
one or two-family residence is included in the permit fee amount set forth in
subsection (a)(1) above.
         (Ord. 3083. Passed 9-12-20.)
 
900.19 APPEALS.
   If it is alleged that any order, requirement, decision or determination made
by an Authority having jurisdiction in the enforcement of the Street and
sidewalk Area Code is unreasonable or in error of law, then the aggrieved party
may appeal said order, requirement, decision or determination in accordance
with the provisions and procedures of Chapter
1119 (Appeals) of the Land Planning and Development Regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.30 PLANNING AND DESIGN.
   The planning and design of work within the scope of the Street and sidewalk
Area Code shall conform to the regulations contained herein; to the planning
principles set forth in Chapter
1150 and the general requirements for improvements set forth in Chapter
1151 of the Land Planning And Development Regulations; and all other applicable
Municipal requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.50 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
   All work within the scope of the Street And sidewalk Area Code shall conform
to the regulations contained herein; to the general requirements for
improvements set forth in Chapter
1151 of the Land Planning And Development Regulations; and all other applicable
Municipal requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY.
 
900.91 PERFORMANCE GUARANTEES.
   (a)    Any contractor, being any person, corporation or other entity,
proposing to do work within any public right of way or easement shall furnish
and file with the Authority having jurisdiction a bond, to be approved as to
form by the Municipal Law Director, in the sum of five-thousand ($5000.00)
dollars guaranteeing full and faithful compliance with all provisions of the
ordinances, specifications and other requirements of the Municipality. Said
contractor shall further furnish evidence of liability insurance for bodily
injury in the minimum amount of one-hundred-thousand dollars/three-hundred-
thousand dollars ($100,000/$300,000), and for property damage in the amount of
fifty-thousand ($50,000) dollars.
 
   (b)    Any developer proposing work within the scope of these regulations
shall be required to post performance guarantees, in accordance with the
provisions therefor set forth in Section
1151.91 (Performance Guarantees) of the Land Planning And Development
Regulations and the following conditions.
      (1)   The Approving Authority for the subject project shall, without
exception, require performance guarantees for an improvement when any variance
is granted to any regulation herein governing said improvement (i.e. any
variance granted to the street regulations shall require a performance
guarantee for all street improvements in the project; variance granted to
requirements of this chapter shall require performance guarantee for all street
and sidewalk area improvements regulated herein).
      (2)   When the Approving Authority for the subject project deems such
guarantees, for the improvements regulated herein, to be necessary and
appropriate to the circumstances of the project so as to insure that public
funds of the Municipality shall not be expended in the event of failure (on the
part of any property owner, developer or contractor) to complete the required
improvements, then the guarantee shall be required.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.92 CONFORM TO APPROVED PLANS.
   Any work done within the scope of these regulations shall be in strict
conformance with the plans and specifications for same as approved by the
Municipality. Any deviation therefrom shall require the specific written
approval of the Municipality in accordance with the provision of Section
900.17 (Variances).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.93 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   All work within the scope of these regulations shall be subject to
inspection and supervision by the Municipality for determination of conformance
with the approved plans, specifications, and applicable Municipal requirements.
The work and materials shall be subject to testing by the Municipality, as may
be appropriate in accordance with accepted engineering practice, for
determination of conformance with the specifications and applicable engineering
standards. The specific requirements for frequency of inspections and
supervision are set forth in the following individual regulations. The cost of
such inspections, supervision and testing shall be paid by the developer in
accordance with the requirements of Section
900.18 (Schedule of Fees).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.94 MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE.
   The developer shall guarantee the materials and workmanship of all
improvements required within this code to be dedicated to public use, and
certain private improvements when so required by a specific improvement
regulation. Said maintenance guarantee shall be in accordance with the terms
and conditions set forth in Section
1151.94 (Maintenance Guarantee) of the Land Planning and Development
Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.95 FORFEITURE OF GUARANTEES.
   When performance, maintenance, or other guarantees have been posted and
thereafter the developer fails to diligently pursue the work; or fails to
complete the installation of the guaranteed improvements; or fails to construct
said improvements in accordance with the approved Construction Document
submittal; or otherwise fails to conform with any terms and/or conditions of
any Municipal approvals or Municipal requirements for the subject project, then
the Municipality, after giving notice which it deems reasonable under the
particular circumstances, shall utilize such monies or bonds as have been
posted.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
900.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this regulation, or the provisions of any
regulation contained in this code for which no other penalty is provided, or
fails to comply with any order issued pursuant to said regulations shall be
charged with, and subject to the penalties for, the following:
      First offense: Minor misdemeanor.
      Second offense: Fourth degree misdemeanor.
      All offenses thereafter: First degree misdemeanor.
   Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)

901.00 GENERAL.
   Definitions for terms used in this regulation are set forth in Chapter
900 of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.01 SCOPE OF REGULATIONS.
   The construction, reconstruction, alteration, extension, enlargement,
excavation, opening, boring under, and repair of any street, whether public or
private, shall be in accordance with these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
901.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   The Public Service Director shall be responsible for the administration and
enforcement of these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.12 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A street work permit is required for all work within the scope of this
regulation. Permit requirements shall be the same as are set forth in Section
900.12 (Permit Requirements).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.13 PROJECT SUBMITTAL PROCEDURE; RECORD DRAWINGS.
   (a)   The submittal of proposed street work or improvements for Municipal
approval shall be in accordance with the requirements of Section
900.13 (Project Submittal Procedures; Record Drawings).
 
   (b)   The submittal of record "as built" drawing for new streets shall be
required. Record drawing for other work within the scope of this regulation may
be required by the Authority having jurisdiction. The submittal of record
drawings shall be in accordance with the requirements of Section
900.13.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.14 STREET CLASSIFICATION MAP.
   The Authority having jurisdiction shall be responsible for maintaining a
Municipal Street Classification Map. This map shall contain the classification
(by function and hierarchy) and the design average daily traffic (ADT) limits
of existing streets within the Corporate limits.
   (a)   When no classification or design ADT limit is established for an
existing street and a new street is proposed which intersects said existing
street, then the Authority having jurisdiction, following consultation with the
Municipal Engineer, shall classify and establish a design ADT level for the
existing street in accordance with the standards set forth in this regulation.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
   (b)   When the Construction Documents for any new street are approved the
street shall be delineated upon said map and annotated as to its classification
in the street hierarchy (see Section
901.35), its design average daily traffic (ADT) limit (see section
901.42) and such other pertinent information as is deemed necessary and
appropriate.
      (Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
   (c)   When any street is reclassified, or its design limits are modified,
the map shall be amended accordingly within thirty (30) days.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.30 PLANNING AND DESIGN.
 
901.31 DESIGN STANDARDS.
   Proposed streets shall be planned, designed and constructed in accordance
with this regulation and as required by the Land Planning and Development
Regulations, Comprehensive Plan, Thoroughfare Plan, Municipal Local Street
Plan, the Ohio Department of Transportation's Location and Design Manual
(Volume 1, Roadway Design), accepted engineering practices and standards,
Municipal Specifications for Streets, and such other adopted regulations and
master plans of the Municipality as may be applicable.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1455. Passed 7-8-93.)
 
901.32 MUNICIPAL SPECIFICATIONS.
   All streets to be dedicated to public use shall be constructed in accordance
with the Municipal Standard Specifications For Streets. Private streets shall
be constructed in accordance with said specification unless otherwise approved
by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.33 EASEMENTS AND RIGHTS OF WAY.
   (a)   Emergency Accessway Easements. Streets shall be laid out to avoid
hazard areas including, but not limited to, flood areas, cliffs, steep slopes
or large ravines. An emergency accessway to a street of equal or higher order,
which access does not go back through the same hazard area, shall be provided
when one of the normal access streets into a development, or portion thereof,
crosses through a hazard area. Said accessways may also be required at the
termination of permanent dead end streets. The intent of said accessway is to
provide an alternate, emergency means of access, for all emergency service
vehicles, to the subject street and buildings thereon should the primary means
of access along said street become impassable. Accessways shall have a minimum
vehicle travel width of twenty (20) feet. The locations of proposed emergency
accessways shall be subject to the approval of the Municipal Approving
Authority for the subject project. The presence of an emergency accessway shall
not qualify a street as a "through street".
      (1)   Emergency accessways shall connect from the subject street to one
of the following, listed in priority, as required by the Approving Authority.
         A.   An existing dedicated street.
         B.   An existing private street on an adjacent property.
         C.   A proposed future street in the subject development.
         D.   An approved driveway, or other path of vehicular travel, which
will meet the above stated intent.
      (2)   The specifications for, and construction of, emergency accessways
shall be adequate to provide for year-round access by all emergency service
vehicles; and shall be subject to the approval of the Municipal Engineer. The
surface material shall be adequate to meet the intent and purpose of the
accessway.
      (3)   The developer shall clearly define the proposed ownership, and the
party responsible for maintenance, of the emergency access way; said proposals
shall be subject to the approval of the Municipal Approving Authority for the
subject project.
      (4)   The developer shall provide an easement, or right of way if
appropriate to the circumstances, to the Municipality for the emergency access
way; such provision shall be noted on the record plat of survey. When the
required right of way or easement will cross property not under the control of
the developer, said developer shall be required to obtain all necessary
property rights across said property; the owner of said property shall be a
signatory to the plat.
 
   (b)   Right of Way Widths. The right of way width requirements enumerated
herein may be modified if found necessary by the Municipal Engineer, and if
approved by the Municipal Approving Authority, because of extraordinary traffic
loads or other just cause. Right-of-way width required for multifamily,
business and industrial development shall be determined for each development to
insure that each street shall be of sufficient width to safely accommodate the
maximum traffic and access for fire protection equipment.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
      (1)   The minimum width of right of way for road purposes shall be sixty
(60) feet.
         (Ord. 439. Passed 8-4-66.)
      (2)   Collector street right-of-way widths shall be in accordance with
Municipal plans and standards and may vary from sixty (60) to seventy (70)
feet.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
      (3)   Major street right-of-way widths shall be in accordance with State
highway or Municipal plans and standards, and may vary from eighty (80) to one-
hundred (100) feet or greater in accordance with Ohio Dept. of Transportation
standards.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.34 INTERSECTION STANDARDS.
   (a)   The intersection of off-street parking lot and loading area driveways
with the street shall conform to the requirements of Chapter
1155 (Required Improvements for Parking Lots and Loading Areas).
 
   (b)   Street intersections shall conform to the following:
      (1)   Local street pavements shall intersect at a ninety (90) degree
angle for a minimum of fifty (50) feet from the intersection of said pavements.
The intersection of higher order streets may require distances greater then 50
ft. based on traffic flow and volume; and shall be subject to approval by the
Municipal Engineer and the Approving Authority.
      (2)   Street intersections shall be located so as to cause the least
interference with the flow of traffic. The intersection of streets with center
line offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. The intersection of
more than two streets at a point shall not be permitted.
      (3)   Property lines at streets intersections shall be rounded with a
radius of not less than thirty (30) feet for local to local street
intersections; thirty-five (35) feet for intersection with collector streets;
and not less than fifty (50) feet for arterial streets.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.35 FUNCTION AND HIERARCHY OF STREETS.
   (a)   In order to promote public safety and convenience, streets shall be
planned to serve particular minimum design functions as set forth herein. The
Municipal street system is herein structured in a hierarchy with the streets
serving the highest function and the heaviest traffic volumes at the highest
level and streets serving the lowest function and the lowest traffic volumes at
the lowest level. All streets shall intersect with other streets of equal or
higher order. Proposed streets shall be planned to carry traffic from the lower
order streets, along streets of progressively higher order, to streets of the
highest order. Streets shall be classified as to function throughout their
entire length based upon the highest function and the highest average daily
traffic (ADT) level which they serve. The classification of a street may
change, over time, as new streets are connected to said street and/or as the
traffic volume on said street increases. Through streets shall be deemed to be
of higher order than dead end streets.
      (1)   STATE and FEDERAL HIGHWAYS: These streets shall be the first and
highest order streets in the hierarchy. They shall be primarily for the
movement of interurban traffic. See the applicable state and federal standards
and regulations for requirements. Lots and building sites abutting State and
Federal highways shall conform to the requirements of Section
901.36 (a) (Marginal access streets).
      (2)   ARTERIAL STREETS: Arterial streets shall be the second highest
order streets in the hierarchy. They shall be primarily for the movement of
fast, heavy traffic between centers of traffic generation. Arterial street
shall be required where shown in the Municipal Thoroughfare Plan and where the
estimated average daily traffic (ADT) volume will exceed the limits established
for collector streets. Arterial streets, unless shown otherwise on the
Thoroughfare Plan, shall be planned for continuation of existing streets in the
system at the same width or greater width in accordance with adopted standards.
Lots and building sites abutting arterial streets shall conform to the
requirements of Section
901.36(a) (Marginal access streets) as applicable. Arterial streets shall be
further subclassified as major arterials and minor arterials.
         A.   Major Arterial: These streets shall be the highest order arterial
streets. They shall be subject to minor access control and shall contain as few
intersections as possible; such intersections shall be channelized. These
streets shall provide connection between state and federal highways to
facilitate the movement of interurban traffic through the community.
         B.   Minor Arterials: These streets shall be the lowest order arterial
streets. They shall function as the main feeder streets with signalization
controls where needed, and stop signs on side streets. These streets may
occasionally form the boundaries of neighborhoods.
      (3)   COLLECTOR STREETS. Collector streets shall be the third level of
streets in the hierarchy. They shall be required where shown on the
Thoroughfare Plan and shall also be required when the average daily traffic
(ADT) anticipated on tile street will exceed the limits established for local
streets. Collector streets shall be the main interior streets. These streets
shall collect, and distribute, traffic between local streets and major streets.
Access to abutting properties shall be subject to the restriction set forth in
this section. Collector streets, unless shown otherwise on the thoroughfare
plan, shall be planned for continuation of existing streets in the system at
the same width or greater width in accordance with adopted standards. Collector
streets will normally contain a relatively large number of intersections with
local streets. Collector streets are herein required, without exception, to be
through streets. Collectors are further subclassified as residential collectors
and general collectors.
         A.   General Collector: These streets shall be the highest order
collector streets. They may service residential and/or nonresidential areas.
These collectors shall provide linkage between lower order and higher order
streets in the hierarchy. Residential lots and building sites abutting general
collector streets shall conform to the requirements of Section
901.36(a) (Marginal access streets). The fronting of, and access to,
nonresidential lots on a general collector is not limited. However, the
location and interval of access drives may be designated by the Approving
Authority when necessary due to existing or anticipated traffic problems.
         B.   Residential Collectors: Residential collector streets shall be
the lowest order collector street. They shall be limited to residential
neighborhood traffic, but provide no, or limited, residential frontage. These
collectors shall be laid out to discourage through traffic, from outside the
development, unless linkage between streets outside of the development is
determined by the Municipal Approving Authority to be desirable. Residential
collectors may be designed based on their average daily traffic level (ADT).
The total frontage of all lots fronting on a residential collector street shall
be limited to a percentage of the total length of the proposed collector street
as follows:
 
 
RESIDENTIAL COLLECTOR LOT FRONTAGE LIMITATIONS
ADT Level                   1000-1199 1200-1599 1600-1999 2000 or >
Maximum percent of frontage 20%       10%       5%        0%
 
      (4)   LOCAL STREETS. Local streets shall be the fourth and lowest order
streets in the hierarchy. They shall provide for access to abutting properties
and circulation of slow moving traffic. Local streets shall be planned for
convenient circulation toward the principal directions of travel. The layout
shall be related to the topography and natural features. It shall be formed of
straight, moderately winding, curved, loop, angular or ell streets; "T"
intersections shall generally predominate. When loop streets are utilized both
ends of the street must intersect the same collecting street; and be laid out
to discourage through traffic. Gridiron, and other rigid geometrical patterns
shall be avoided. Local streets shall be further subclassified as general,
residential subcollector, and residential access.
         A.   Local General: These streets shall be the highest order local
streets. They shall be utilized to serve non-residential lots and building
sites; and shall be used in residential development where the ADT levels will
not be fixed or cannot be accurately determined. Local general streets may
intersect with, or take access from, any other street.
         B.   Residential Subcollector: These streets shall be the intermediate
order of local streets.They shall serve to move traffic from access streets to
collector streets in residential areas only. Access to abutting lots shall not
be limited. These streets may intersect with, or take access from, any other
streets type. Residential subcollectors may be designed based on their expected
average daily traffic (ADT) levels.
         C.   Residential Access: These streets shall be the lowest order local
street. They shall serve only residential lots and building sites. They shall
be designed so that no individual street conveys more traffic than that which
originates on, or is destine to, the street itself. These streets may
intersect, or take access from, any other street type. They shall be designed
to create quiet neighborhood environments. Residential access streets may be
designed based on their expected average daily traffic (ADT) levels.
 
   (b)   Local streets for business and industrial developments shall be
planned to connect with arterial, general collector, or other local general
streets so as to not generate large volumes of traffic on any residential
street. Local street for multifamily buildings and. developments shall be
planned to connect with arterial, general collector, or a residential collector
or subcollector (subject to ADT limits), so as not to generate unnecessary
traffic on residential access streets.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.36 SPECIAL PURPOSE STREETS.
   (a)   Marginal Access Streets. Marginal access streets shall provide access
to properties abutting State and Federal highways, and major arterial streets
in order to protect said properties from the movement of heavy traffic, reduce
traffic congestion due to turning maneuvers, and to eliminate multiple
driveways intersecting with said streets. In addition, residential properties
abutting minor arterials and general collectors shall be protected in like
manner as provided for herein.
      (1)   Where a proposed subdivision or planned unit development abuts any
of the streets noted in (a) above the Planning Commission may require the
developer to improve and dedicate marginal access streets to serve the access
requirements of any lots or building sites which are proposed to front upon
said major streets.
      (2)   New one and/or two family residential lots or building sites shall
neither front directly on, nor have their driveways intersecting directly with,
an arterial or general collector street. In order to insure the public safety,
a marginal access street, or similar accessway, shall be provided to act as a
buffer between the residential property and the arterial or collector street
for the same reasons as set forth in (a) above. Lots of record existing on or
before the first effective date of this regulation shall be exempt from the
marginal access street requirement provided that said lots are not subdivided
thereafter.
 
   (b)   Permanent Dead-End Streets. Local streets may be permitted to be
permanent dead end streets in the following circumstances subject to the
approval of the Municipal Approving Authority for the project:
      (1)   Where parcels are isolated by surrounding existing developments;
and no provisions exist on surrounding properties to allow connection with an
existing or proposed street.
      (2)   Where parcels, or portions there of, are of unusual configuration
and/or pockets exist thereon that are most efficiently served by dead end
streets (see limitations; section
901.61 (Minimum Street Standards).
      (3)   Where continuous streets would require excessive grading because of
very irregular topography.
      (4)   Where other types of non-through streets would not provide
sufficient discouragement of through traffic.
      (5)   When used to create small residential neighborhood environments in
accordance with the ADT limitations prescribed in Section
901.61 (Minimum Street Standards). Emergency accessways (see Section
901.33(a)) may be required, when and where appropriate, by the Approving
Authority. Permanent dead-end streets shall be terminated in accordance with
the requirements of Section
901.59 (Permanent Dead End Streets). All permanent dead-end residential
subcollector streets shall take their access from a through street.
 
   (c)   Temporary Dead-end streets. Temporary dead end streets shall be
permitted only where they are designed and intended for future continuation
(either in a subsequent phase of the subject project or upon undeveloped
adjacent lands) in accordance with the requirements of Section
901.56 (Provide for future connections). Temporary dead-end streets shall be
terminated in accordance with the requirements of Section
901.59 (Permanent Dead End Streets) unless otherwise approved by the Approving
Authority. In phased development projects, a street which is shown in a
currently approved concept and/or preliminary submittal as a through street
shall be considered as a through street for planning and design purposes even
though its construction may not be completed. A street intended for extension
to adjacent undeveloped lands may be considered as a through street for
planning and design purposes when, in the opinion of the Municipal Approving
Authority, Municipal regulations are adequate to cause the its completion as a
through street upon said adjacent lands.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.37 NONCONFORMING STREET WIDTH.
   Streets of less than the required width shall not be permitted. Where
property abuts an existing street which does not conform to the width as
required by the thoroughfare plan or these regulations, or plans of the County
Highway Department or State Department of Transportation, the additional width
shall be dedicated when the land is subdivided or development is proposed upon
the abutting property.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.38 RESERVE STRIPS.
   Reserve strips adjoining streets, or other provisions to control access or
extensions to pavement and/or utilities to another property, shall not be
permitted except where provisions for the control and disposal of land
comprising such strips has been assigned to the Municipality under conditions
approved by the Commission.
(Ord. 460. Passed 11-16-67.)
 
901.39 TOPOGRAPHY AND STREETS.
   The development shall be planned so that as many lots as possible will be
above-the street grade. On irregular topography, streets shall be designed to
avoid extensive cuts and fills and to comply with grading standards established
herein and for private driveways and yards (see Chapters
1155 (Parking Lots and Loading Areas);
1153 (Grading and Surface Water Drainage)) as well as for the streets. Streets
approximately parallel to contour lines shall be adjusted so that the lots on
one side of the street will not be excessively below the street grade.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.40 BLOCK DESIGN.
   Blocks shall be designed in accordance with the requirements for same set
forth in Chapter
1147 (Land Planning Requirements) of the Land Development Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.41 GEOMETRIC DESIGN CRITERIA.
   (a)   The geometric design criteria for public and private streets shall be
as set forth in the Ohio Department of Transportation, "Location and Design
Manual, Volume 1 - Roadway Design", and as thereafter amended.
 
   (b)   Where the above standard does not define design criteria at lower
speeds, then the American Association of State Highway and Transportation
Officials (AASHTO) 1984 publication "A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways
and Streets", and as thereafter amended, shall supplement the ODOT criteria. In
this instance the proposed design criteria shall be subject to the approval of
the Municipal Engineer and the Approving Authority for the project.
 
   (c)   The minimum design speed for residential access streets shall be
twenty (20) miles per hour.
(Ord. 1455. Passed 7-8-93.)
 
901.42 ADT CALCULATIONS.
   (a)   When the provisions of Section
901.35 (Function and Hierarchy) specifically provide for certain streets to be
planned and design based on expected average daily traffic (ADT) levels, the
computation of said traffic levels shall be in accordance with the requirements
and restrictions set forth herein. The trip generation standards set forth
herein are based on nationally accepted standards and shall receive specific
attention during the annual regulation review required by Section
900.15.
 
   (b)   The use of this method of performance based street design is elective
on the part of the developer. When the developer elects not to utilize this
method, or the ADT levels for the proposed streets cannot be adequately
determined, then the proposed streets shall be planned and designed in
accordance with the "General" street standards of Section
901.61 (Minimum Street Standards) based on the function of the proposed
streets.
 
   (c)   This method of design may be used when all of the following criterion
can be met:
      (1)   These standards are applicable only to residential streets and do
not apply to streets serving commercial or industrial properties.
      (2)   The streets and lots, or building sites, must be designed so as to
define all dwelling units to be served and to preclude future construction of
additional dwelling units which are not included in the ADT calculations.
      (3)   The street layout must be designed so as not to encourage through
traffic from other areas which are not included in the ADT calculations.
 
   (d)   The expected average daily traffic level for a street, or series of
streets, shall be determined based on the expected number of daily trips
generated by all dwelling units served by said street, or streets. The expected
number of daily trips, to and from a dwelling unit, for various types of
dwellings shall be as follows:
 
 
TRIP GENERATION STANDARDS
                         AVERAGE WEEKDAY TRIP GENERATION RATE
HOUSING TYPE
Single family-detached   10.0 Trips/D.U.*
Single family-attached** 8.1 Trips/D.U.
Apartment building***    6.1 Trips/D.U.
Mobile home park         5.0 Trips/D.U.
Retirement community     3.3 Trips/D.U.
 
   *   Trips per dwelling unit.
   **   Includes duplexes, townhouses, and similar multiple-single family
dwellings where each dwelling unit has its own separate entrance.
   ***   Includes any building, having three or more dwelling units, where
dwelling units share a common entrance. When a particular type of dwelling is
not specifically listed, then the listed type which it most closely resembles
shall be used.
 
   (e)   Computation of ADT. A dwelling unit is deemed to contribute traffic to
a particular street if the driveway serving the dwelling intersects with said
street. Should a dwelling have a driveway which intersects two different
streets then the traffic generated on each street shall be one-half (½) of the
total trips generated by the dwelling.
      (1)   The total trips generated by each type of dwelling on a subject
street shall be calculated by multiplying the total number of dwelling units of
each type times the appropriate trip generation rate.
      (2)   The total trips generated on a subject street shall be the sum of
the trip totals for each type of dwelling on said street plus the sum of the
ADT levels for all other streets which intersect with the subject street.
      (3)   The ADT for the subject street shall be established at its first
point of intersection with another street, or streets, of equal or higher order
in the street hierarchy. When a street qualifies as a through street the ADT at
each intersection shall be one-half (½) of the total trips generated on the
subject street. When a street qualifies as a dead-end then the ADT at the
intersection which provides access to a higher order street shall be the total
trips generated on the subject street; should another intersection exist its
ADT value shall be zero (0).
      (4)   The calculated ADT levels for each street, at its intersection with
another street or equal or higher order, shall be within the applicable ADT
range limits (see Section
901.61 (Minimum Street Standards), for the subject street function (local
residential access, residential subcollector, etc.).
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.43 CONNECTING WITH EXISTING STREETS.
   (a)   Proposed streets shall be planned and designed to integrate with, and
compliment, the existing street system. The planning and design considerations
thereof shall be subject to the approval of the Municipal Approving Authority
for the project. Should the Approving Authority determine that the proposed
street layout, design, classification or other characteristics thereof are not
adequate, in the Authority's opinion, then the developer shall make such
modifications as are necessary to meet the requirements of the Approving
Authority.
 
   (b)   No new street which intersects with an existing street shall generate
additional traffic onto the existing street in such volume as to cause
reclassification of the existing street (see Section
901.14) due to the anticipated increase in traffic volume on the existing
street (see ADT limits; Section
901.61). No new street shall intersect with an existing street when such
intersection will cause reclassification of the existing street due to a change
in function of the existing street (see Section
901.35). Variance to these limitations will be considered by Council only when
no other alternative is available to the developer; and shall, if granted,
shall be subject to such special terms, conditions and other requirements as
may be required by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.44 STREET NAMES.
   Street names shall be selected which will not duplicate or be confused with
the names of existing streets in Geauga County, irrespective of modifying terms
such as streets, avenue, boulevard, etc. Streets that are or will eventually be
continuations of existing or platted streets shall be named the same. Street
names shall be subject to the approval of the Planning Commission and wherever
possible shall be in accordance with the following system:
 
 
General Direction   Long Continuous   Short Disconnected
North-South      Streets         Courts
East-West      Avenues      Places
Diagonal      Roads         Ways
Curving      Drives         Lanes or Circles
 
(Ord. 460. Passed 11-16-67.)
 
901.50 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
 
901.51 INSTALLATION REQUIRED.
   The improvements required herein are deemed the minimum necessary provisions
for the protection of the Municipality's street system; providing safe and
suitable access to property; and for providing essential services for the
protection of the public safety, health and general welfare. The improvements
required herein shall be provided, installed and/or constructed by the
developer at his expense and as herein required.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.52 DEDICATION TO PUBLIC USE.
   All new streets shall be dedicated to public use unless otherwise approved
by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.53 RESPONSIBILITY FOR WORK.
   The developer shall provide and install, at his expense, the streets and
other associated improvements required by these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.54 EXTENSION OF EXISTING STREETS.
   When a subject development property abuts an easement, or right of way,
which provides for the extension, or continuation, of existing streets from
adjacent lands, the developer of the subject property shall be required to
install such street improvements as are necessary to connect with the pavement
existing on, or adjacent to, said easement or right of way so as to provide a
continuous street system.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.55 REQUIRED STREET CONNECTIONS.
   Proposed streets shall connect with existing streets of equal or higher
order.
   (a)   When provisions exist upon lands adjacent to a subject. project for
the extension of existing streets, or the construction of connecting streets,
onto the subject development area, the developer of the subject project shall
provide and install all necessary improvements to extend said streets into the
subject development area and connect said streets to other existing or proposed
streets in a manner approved by the Municipal Approving Authority.
   (b)   When emergency accessways on adjacent lands have been planned to be
extended into the subject development project, the developer of the subject
project shall complete the extension of said accessways so as to connect same
to a proposed street, or other approved place, in the subject development
project. The extension of said accessways shall be in accordance with the
requirements of section (Emergency Accessways).
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.56 PROVIDE FOR FUTURE CONNECTIONS.
   When the subject property abuts undeveloped lands, the developer shall
extended streets, and rights of way for same, to the property line in a manner,
and in such locations, as the Approving Authority for the subject project may
reasonably require in accordance with accepted land planning and engineering
standards and practices so as to provide for the continuation of service to
said undeveloped lands in the future. When, in accordance with the Land
Development Regulations, the present construction of street pavement is not
warranted, the developer shall be required to provide the necessary street
rights of way to connect with the adjacent land. When such temporary dead-end
streets are required, or proposed, they shall conform to the requirements set
forth herein for their future extension onto adjacent lands.
   (a)   The location of the street and its point of intersection with the
adjacent property line, or approved construction phase line, shall be
appropriate to provide for the future connecting street on adjacent lands to be
in conformance with the design standards set forth in Section
901.31 (Design Standards). Said location shall be subject to the approval of
the Municipal Approving Authority.
   (b)   All street pavement intersections, and other improvements associated
therewith, shall be constructed. All required improvements shall be constructed
beyond the intersection to a point approved by the Municipal Approving
Authority for the subject project.
   (c)   When lots, or building sites, are proposed to front upon the dead-end
portion of the street, and said portion of the street is more than two-hundred
(200) feet in length, a turn-around shall be provided at the termination of the
street pavement. The turn-around shall conform to the same requirements as are
set forth for termination of permanent dead-end streets. Provisions shall be
made, and noted on the record plat of survey, for reversion of the excess
right-of-way to the abutting properties at such time as the street is extended.
   (d)   When the purpose of said street, or the future extension thereof, will
be to connect with adjacent lands of different ownership than the subject
project, the subject developer shall further provide a dedicated right of way
for said street, conforming to these regulations. Said right of way shall begin
at an existing or proposed dedicated street and shall extend to the property
line of said adjacent lands.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.57 STREET OPENING AND BORING.
   No person, other than authorized Municipal employees, shall make any opening
or excavation in, or tunnel under, any street, alley, sidewalk or public way of
the Municipality without first obtaining the permit required by Section
901.12 (Permit Required) of this regulation.
   (a)   Prior to the issuance of said permit the applicant shall deposit, with
the Authority having jurisdiction, such Bond documents as are required by
Section
901.91 (Performance Guarantee) and such fees and deposits as are required by
Section
900.18 (Schedule of Fees) of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
   (b)   When she purpose of the excavation is the installation of, or
connection to, Municipal water lines, storm sewers or sanitary sewers the
applicant shall further pay any and all applicable charges, fees, and deposits
associated therewith (see Public Utilities Code Section
920.18 (Schedule of Fees); Chapter
921 (Water Service Charges); Chapter
923 (Sanitary Sewer Charges)).
   (c)   All street work shall be in conformance with the terms and conditions
of the approved permit and this regulation. Work shall be in conformance with
applicable Municipal specification and regulations. Any deviation from the
approved permit requirements shall require the prior written approval of the
Authority having jurisdiction.
   (d)   The excavation shall be backfilled, and the street pavement, curbs,
tree lawn, sidewalk, all other public improvements, and any damage to private
property shall be restored by the applicant, at his expense, in conformance
with the applicable Municipal Standard Specifications and subject to the
approval of the Municipal inspector.
   (e)   Should the applicant fail to complete all work in accordance with
Municipal requirements the Municipality shall cause such completion of work,
repairs or corrective actions as are necessary and shall proceed in accordance
with the provisions of Section
900.95 (Forfeiture of Guarantees).
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.58 MUNICIPAL UTILITIES.
   (a)   Where sanitary sewers, storm sewers or water lines are not in
existence, the same shall be provided and installed, in accordance with the
requirements of the Public Service Code, prior to the construction of curbs,
base or pavement.
 
   (b)   When municipal utilities are in existence, manholes, valves boxes and
other surface appurtenances shall be brought to the grade line of the finished
road.
 
   (c)   Any work involving Municipal utilities shall be in accordance with the
applicable municipal regulations, standards and specifications.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.59 PERMANENT DEAD END STREETS.
   When permanent dead end streets are permitted they shall be terminated with
a circle turn- around, or modification thereof, conforming to the following
requirements. Emergency accessways may be required by the Approving Authority.
   (a)   The turn-around area shall be of such configuration, size and pavement
specification so as to adequately handle the expected traffic flow and types of
vehicles which may utilize the area; the proposed configuration and dimensions
shall be subject to approval by the Municipal Engineer and the Authority having
jurisdiction.
   (b)   When, in the opinion of the Municipal Engineer, the expected traffic
conditions and vehicle types are conducive to its use the minimum standards for
a cul-de-sac shall be as follows.
      (1)   The right of way radius shall be seventy-five (75) feet; the outer
edge of pavement radius shall be fifty-five (55) feet; the center portion of
the cul-de-sac shall be paved. The pavement specification shall conform the
applicable section of these regulations.
      (2)   When an inner portion of the cul-de-sac is to be landscaped, these
dimensions shall be increased accordingly. The pavement width shall conform to
the applicable requirements of these regulations based on the function of the
street being terminated. Landscaped, or open center configurations shall not be
accepted on streets to be dedicated to public use or on temporary cul-de-sacs.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.60 GRADING AND DRAINAGE.
   (a)   Streets shall level off to a grade not exceeding three percent for a
distance of not less than 100 feet from each side of a local to local street
intersection. The Municipal Engineer may require a distance greater than 100
feet, in accordance with accepted practice, for intersections involving higher
order streets.
 
   (b)   The maximum vertical grades of streets shall not exceed ten (10%)
percent for local streets, seven (7%) percent for collector streets, and six
(6%) percent for arterial streets.
 
   (c)   The grading of the roadway shall extend the full width of the right of
way. Tree lawns shall be graded at a gradient of not less than two (2%) percent
or more than five (5%) percent upward from the curb to the sidewalk or property
line.
 
   (d)   Streets shall be graded for the positive drainage of storm water. For
drainage purposes street grades shall be not less than one (1%) percent in
order to provide adequate surface drainage. However, the Approving Authority,
following consultation with the Municipal Engineer, may permit a minimum street
grade of one-half of one (0.5%) percent where necessary because of topographic
or other conditions. Storm sewers shall be provided and installed with adequate
capacity to handle drainage from the street and such storm water as may be
directed thereto from adjacent lands (see Chapter
929 (Storm Sewer Regulations)).
 
   (e)   After the street base finish grading has been completed, and prior to
the installation of the street pavement, the developer’s engineer or surveyor
shall provide to the Authority Having Jurisdiction, written certification based
on an actual field survey that the street base field location, grade elevations
and cross slope elevations comply with the plans approved by the Municipality.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1918. Passed 7-8-99.)
 
901.61 MINIMUM STREET STANDARDS.
   All new streets shall, at a minimum, conform to the standards set forth
herein. The required width of pavements shall not be less than required herein
based on the function and traffic load of the proposed street improvement. The
material specifications for streets (including, but not limited to, sub-base,
base, pavement, curbs and gutters) shall be in accordance with the Municipal
Standards Specification for Streets based on the function and traffic load of
the proposed street improvement.
   (a)
 
ARTERIAL STREETS

              25000

   (b)
 
COLLECTOR STREETS
SERVICE LEVEL ADT LIMIT       SPEED LIMIT PV’MT WIDTTRAVEL LANE RIGHT OF WAY
WIDTH                                                 NO./WIDTH

Residential   >500;< = 1500   35 MPH      24 ft.      2/ 12-12    60 ft.

street intersections in areas of high traffic volume or where significant
traffic congestion exists, or is anticipated.
Note:    All Collector streets shall be through streets.
   (c)

   (d)   The width of the pavement shall be measured from face of curb to face
of curb.
   (e)   The pavement requirements enumerated above, and in the Municipal
Street Specifications, may be modified if found necessary by the Municipal
Engineer and if approved by the Municipal Approving Authority, because of
extraordinary traffic loads.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.62 CURBS AND GUTTERS.
   (a)   Vertical faced concrete curbs and gutter, or vertical faced concrete
curbs and gutters integral with pavement shall be provided. Curb type shall
conform to Municipal specifications. Rolled curb shall be prohibited.
 
   (b)   Curb cuts for driveways and/or handicap sidewalk ramps shall conform
to the Municipal specifications for same.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.63 PUBLIC SIDEWALKS.
   Sidewalks shall be designed, located and constructed in accordance with
requirements of Chapter
905 (Sidewalk Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.64 MONUMENTS.
   A monument shall be accurately placed at each street intersection, at points
of curves of streets, and at intermediate points and at other locations as may
be required by the Municipal Engineer in accordance with accepted engineering
practices and standards. The monuments shall conform to municipal
specifications. The top of the monument shall be set at the finish grade upon
completion of the grading of the streets and the lots.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.65 STREET TREES.
   Street trees shall be selected, located and planted in accordance with the
Municipal Street Tree Plan and the requirements of Chapter
909 (Trees).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.66 STREET NAME SIGNS.
   Street name signs shall be furnished and installed by the developer. The
signs shall conform to the Ohio Department of Transportation'S Manual of
Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highway (or thereafter the
applicable standard in that category). Signs shall be placed on diagonally
opposite corners, on the far right hand of the intersection for traffic on the
more important street, and as close to the corner as possible.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.67 TRAFFIC SIGNS AND SIGNALS.
   All traffic control signs, markings and devices required by the Municipality
shall be furnished and installed by the developer. Said signs, markings and
devices shall conform to the specifications of the Ohio Department of
Transportation (see Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.68 STREET LIGHTING.
   Street lighting shall be provided by the developer on all streets. Electric
service shall be installed underground. Lighting levels shall conform to Ohio
Department of Transportation requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY.
 
901.91 PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE.
   (a)   Any contractor proposing to do work within a dedicated right of way,
or municipal easement, shall be bonded in accordance with the requirements of
Section
900.91(a) (Performance Guarantee) of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
 
   (b)   Any developer proposing work within the scope of these regulations
shall post such performance guarantees as may be required in accordance with
Section
900.91(b) (Performance Guarantee) of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.92 CONFORM TO APPROVED PLAN.
   Any work done within the scope of these regulations shall be in strict
conformance with the plans and specifications for same as approved by the
Municipality. Any deviation therefrom shall require the prior specific written
approval of the Approving Authority for the subject project (see Chapter
1111 (Municipal Approvals Required); Land Planning and Development
Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.93 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   All work within the scope of these regulations shall be subject to full time
inspection and supervision by the Municipality in accordance with the
provisions of Section
900.93 of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.94 MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE.
   Upon completion of construction of any streets (whether public or private)
the developer shall post a maintenance guarantee for said streets guaranteeing
against defects in material and workmanship. Said guarantee shall be in
accordance with the terms and conditions set forth for same in Section
900.94 (Maintenance Guarantee) of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code. Thereafter
the responsibility for the maintenance repairs for streets dedicated to public
use shall rest with the Municipality; the responsibility for maintenance
repairs for private streets shall rest with the property owner.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
901.99 PENALTY.
   The penalty for any violation of this regulation, or any order issued
pursuant thereto, shall be the same as is set forth in Section
900.99 (Penalty) of the Street and Sidewalk Area Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
