920.00 GENERAL.
 
920.001 DEFINITIONS.
   The terms defined in this chapter shall have, throughout the Public
Utilities Code, the meanings stated. When words used herein are defined in
other regulations (including but not limited to the Zoning Ordinance, Street
and Sidewalk Area Code, and Land Planning and Development Regulations) the
words shall have the meaning therein defined. When words are not otherwise
defined they shall carry their customary meanings as defined in Webster's
Standard Dictionary. Words used in the singular include the plural; and the
plural the singular. Words used in the present tense include the future tense.
The word "shall" is intended to be mandatory. The word "may" is directive and
to be complied with unless waived.
 
   "Approved laboratory procedures" means the measurements, tests and analysis
of the characteristics of water and wastes in accordance with analytical
procedures determined acceptable by Federal guidelines as established in Title
40, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 136, or as approved by the Regional
Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
 
   "Biochemical oxygen demand (or B.O.D.)" means the quantity of oxygen,
expressed in mg/l, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter
under standard laboratory conditions for 5 days at a temperature of 20 degrees
centigrade. The laboratory determination shall be in accordance with approved
laboratory procedures.
 
   "Capital budget" means a separate budget dedicated to financing capital
improvements.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Development" shall mean any man-made change to improved or unimproved real
property, the use of any principal structure or land, or any other activity
that requires issuance of a site development permit and/or zoning permit.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Development subareas" shall mean geographically defined areas of the
Municipality that have been designated in the comprehensive plan as areas in
which development potential may create the need for capital improvements
program to be funded by impact fees.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Development subarea map" shall mean a map of development subareas in which
impact fees are imposed. This map is attached to this ordinance and
incorporated by reference herein as if fully set out.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Discharge" means the discharge of wastewater from premises at its point of
entry in the sewerage system.
 
   "Direct tap" means a connection to any Municipal utility system which is
made directly into a water or sewer main dedicated to public use.
 
   "Domestic waste": See "normal sewage".
 
   "Drainage way" means any surface water drainage swale, drainage ditch, open
channel waterway, receiving waterway, natural stream or water course, and any
easement or right of way associated therewith.
 
   "Enclosed storm sewer" means the entirety of sewer pipes, inlet basins,
manholes, and other appurtenances install at, or below, grade for the
collection and removal of storm water.
 
   "Indirect discharge" means: 1. A discharge into any private service lateral
or private sewer main, which lateral or main ultimately connects to a Municipal
sewer system. 2. The discharge into any sewage or waste pretreatment facility,
or any other sewage or waste processing system, which facility or system is
connected to the Municipal sewerage system. 3. The introduction of pollutants
into a publicly owned treatment works from any nondomestic source regulated
under Section 307(b), (c), or (d) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act
(33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq.).
 
   "Indirect tap" means any connection made to a private water or sewer pipe
which ultimately connects to any Municipal utility system.
 
   "Industrial waste" means the solid, liquid or gaseous wastes resulting from
any industrial, manufacturing, trade or business process.
 
   "Municipal storm sewer system" means the entirety of inlet basins, enclosed
storm sewers, open drainage ways and receiving waterways planned, constructed,
and/or designated to provide for the drainage of storm water from public
properties and private storm sewer systems throughout the Municipality.
 
   "Municipal storm water drainage plan" means the mapped and written portions
of the Comprehensive plan regarding existing and proposed storm water drainage
facilities.
 
   "Normal sewage" means sewage which when analyzed shows by weight a daily
average of not more than 250 parts per million of suspended solids; not more
than 200 parts per million B.O.D.; not more than 8 parts per million
phosphorus; and not more than 25 parts per million ammonia-nitrogen.
 
   "Oils and greases" means those materials extractable from an acidified
sample by freon or other acceptable solvent in accordance with approved
laboratory procedures.
 
   "Organic" means containing carbon compounds.
 
   "Primary water line" is the service line within a structure which provides
water for human consumption and use and which is discharged into the sanitary
sewer system.
 
   "Primary water line water meter" is the water meter which measures the water
flowing through the primary water line.
 
   "Private storm sewer system" means the entirety of drainage ways, inlet
basins and enclosed storm sewers beginning at the point of discharge into the
Municipal storm sewer system and continuing upstream onto a private property to
the end of any open drainage ways upon said property. Said system serving the
drainage needs of only the subject property.
 
   "Receiving waterway" means any natural stream or watercourse designated by
Council or the Planning Commission to receive the discharge from the Municipal
storm sewer system and/or the Municipal wastewater treatment plant.
 
   "Residential development" means any development approved by the local
government for residential use.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer which carries domestic and/or industrial
wastewater and to which storm, surface and ground waters are not admitted.
 
   "Secondary water line" is the service line from the inside of the structure
to an outside faucet or faucets and other water distribution devices, which
provide water used solely outside of the structure and does not drain into the
sanitary sewer system.
 
   "Secondary water line water meter" is the water meter which measures the
water flowing through the secondary water line.
 
   "Service lateral" means a pipe connecting any water or sewer main with a
user's building or facility.
 
   "Sewer Main" means the piped portion of a sanitary sewer or storm sewer
which receives the discharge from service laterals.
 
   "Sewer tap-in permit" means the permit required for new user connections to
the municipal sanitary sewer system.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Sewage": See "normal sewage".
 
   "Sewerage system" means all of the facilities required to transport sewage
from the premises of the source to a sewage treatment facility, and includes
the treatment and disposal facility. All such facilities of the Municipality
shall be considered one such sewerage system.
 
   "Sewer service charge" means the total charge to a sewerage system user.
 
   "Site" means the land on which development takes place.
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are
in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by
laboratory filtering.
 
   "User" means any person, corporation or other entity having, causing, or
permitting the use of, an active user connection to a Municipal utility system.
 
   "Wastewater" means a combination of liquid and water carried wastes.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
   "Water main" means the piped portions of the water distribution system which
supply water to service laterals.
(Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
 
   "User connection" means a connection to any Municipal utility system,
whether by direct or indirect tap, whereby any person, corporation or other
entity gains service from said system.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
   "Zoning districts" (See Zoning Ord. definitions, Chapter
1111)
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
 
   "Zoning ordinance" (See Zoning Ord. definitions, Chapter
1111)
(Ord. 1439. Passed 3-22-93.)
(Ord. 1864. Passed 12-10-98; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
920.002 CITATION.
   These regulations, rules and standards for the planning, design,
construction, operation and maintenance of Municipal utilities (including, but
not limited to, the water supply system, sanitary sewerage system, storm sewer
system and any private service, system or facility connected thereto) and
further including procedures to be followed in the application and
administration of these regulation, and the penalties for any violation
thereof, shall be known, cited and referred to as the Public Utilities Code
(codified as Title Three of this Part Nine - Streets, Utilities and Public
Service Code).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.003 PURPOSE.
   The general purpose of these regulations shall be to guide and regulate the
planning, design, construction operation and maintenance of Municipal
utilities, and any private service, system or other private facility connected
thereto, in order to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of
the Municipality.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.004 OBJECTIVES.
   It is intended that the provisions of these regulations shall be to achieve
the following objectives.
   (a)   Provide an appropriate and accessible system of public utilities for
the community.
   (b)   Insure adequate and economical provisions for utility services in
order to conserve the public funds.
   (c)   Provide for the development and expansion of the public utility
systems to support current service requirements and desirable community growth.
   (d)   Eliminate sewage and other waste disposal practices which may cause
environmental degradation or which threaten public health and welfare.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.005 VALIDITY.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or other phrase of these
regulations is, for any reason, held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be
invalid, such decision shall not effect the remaining portion of these
regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.006 CONFLICT.
   (a)   When a conflict arises herein between a general requirement and a
specific requirement, the specific requirements shall prevail.
 
   (b)   When a conflict arises between a requirement in these regulations and
a requirement in another regulation the resolution shall be in accordance with
the provisions of sections
101.06 and
101.07 of the Municipal Administrative Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.007 COPIES OF REGULATIONS.
   The Municipality shall make available to developers copies of these Public
Utilities Code and other adopted plans, regulations and information, as are
associated therewith, at a cost to be determined by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.008 REQUIREMENTS ARE MINIMUM.
   The improvements required by these regulations (including but not limited
to; water lines, sanitary sewers and storm sewers) are herein deemed the
minimum improvements necessary in the public interest to provide essential
services and protect the public health, safety and general welfare. Said
improvements shall be provided and installed by the developer, at his expense,
in accordance with all applicable Municipal requirements and regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.01 SCOPE OF REGULATION.
   The planning, design, construction, operation and maintenance of Municipal
utilities (including, but not limited to, the water supply system, sanitary
sewerage system, storm sewer system and any private service, system or other
private facility connected thereto) shall be in accordance with these
regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
920.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   Except as otherwise provided for herein, the Public Service Director shall
be responsible for the administration and enforcement of these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.12 PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
   No work within the scope of the Public Utilities Code shall commence without
first obtaining the necessary approvals and permits from the Municipality and
paying all required fees.
   (a)   Work permits shall be issued by the Authority having jurisdiction for
the regulation governing the work upon application and after all necessary
approvals have been granted.
   (b)   Proposed work which is an integral part of a development project which
is subject to a Site Development Permit, and which work shall be accomplished
at the time of initial construction of said project, shall not require a
separate work permit. However, said work shall conform with all other
requirements of this regulation and the regulations contained in this code.
   (c)   When, in the opinion of the Authority having jurisdiction, the
proposed work may be classified as a minor repair, and the proposed work will
be done in accordance with all other requirements of these regulations, the
permit requirement may be waived.
   (d)   Permit fees shall be as set forth in Section
920.18.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1750. Passed 5-8-97; Am. Ord. 1990.
Passed 5-11-00.)
 
920.13 PROJECT SUBMITTAL PROCEDURE; RECORD DRAWINGS.
   (a)   The submittal of proposed work or improvements within the scope of the
Public Utilities Coder shall be in accordance with the requirements of the Land
Planning and Development Regulations for the construction project of which they
are a part (see Chapter
1145 (Procedure)).
      (1)   When the proposed work is not an integral part of a larger project
then the submittal shall be in accordance with the requirements for single
building site development (see Lands and Improvements For Public Use; Section
1145.03 Project Classification).
      (2)   Drawings and specifications for the proposed work and/or
improvements shall be reviewed by, and shall subject to the approval of, the
Municipal Engineer and such other reviewing authorities as may be designated by
the Municipal Approving Authority for the subject project. The Municipal
Engineer's review and approval shall include, but is not necessarily limited
to, planning and design standards, required improvements, accepted engineering
practices and standards. Copies of all design calculations shall be submitted
for review by, and shall be subject to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer.
 
   (b)   Within sixty (60) days of the completion of construction of
improvements the developer shall furnish the Municipality a set of record "as
built" drawings of the improvements when so required by the regulations
contained herein. Said record drawings shall conform to the requirements of
Chapter
1151 (Submittal Content Requirements) and the Municipal Standards For Plan
Contents.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.14 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Authority having jurisdiction may adopt, subject to the approval of
Council, such rules and regulations as may be necessary and appropriate for the
effective administration and enforcement of the Public Utilities Code. Said
rules and regulations shall have the same force and effect as ordinances when
not repugnant thereto or to State law.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.15 ANNUAL REVIEW OF REGULATION.
   The Authority having jurisdiction shall review the Public Utilities Code on
an annual basis. Said review shall include, but is not limited to, insuring the
continued validity of all regulations; insuring the absence of conflicts within
these regulations and in their relationship to other regulations; and the
development and proposal of such additional amendments as are deemed necessary
and appropriate.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.16 AMENDMENTS.
   Amendments to these regulations may be initiated by the Authorities having
jurisdiction or Council. If initiated by an Authority having jurisdiction, then
they shall first be subject to review by such committees and/or consultants as
is required by policy of Council. Amendments shall be subject to such public
hearings as may be necessary to conform to applicable requirements of R.C. §
711.101. If the amendment is approved by Council then an amending ordinance may
be adopted by a majority vote thereof.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.17 VARIANCES.
   (a)   The Municipality may consider variances to certain Planning and Design
Standards set forth in the regulations of this Code. Variances to other
standards, requirements, procedures or regulations contained herein shall not
be considered. No variance to, and no modification of requirements to conform
with, any of the following standards and/or regulations shall be considered
unless specific provisions are otherwise noted in said standard or regulation.
      (1)   No "Municipal Standard Specification" shall be varied.
      (2)   No "minimum" planning and design standard shall be varied.
 
   (b)   Variance to this Code shall be regulated by, and in accordance with,
the provisions of this section, Section
920.91 and Chapter
1119 (Variances) of the Land Planning and Development Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.18 SCHEDULE OF FEES.
   The rates and charges for water and sanitary sewer services shall be as set
forth in Chapters
921 and
923 respectively. The fees associated with the administration and enforcement
of the Public Utilities Code shall be as provided for herein. Said fees shall
be paid as prescribed herein; and shall be in addition to any other fees
required by other Municipal regulations.
   (a)   Permit fees. Paid at time of permit application submittal.
      (1)   Water service line permit: one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00).
      (2)   Sanitary sewer lateral permit: ninety dollars ($90.00).
      (3)   Storm sewer lateral permit: one hundred ten dollars ($110.00).
      (4)   Second water meter permit: one hundred forty dollars ($140.00).
         (Ord. 2112. Passed 4-11-02.)
 
   (b)   Deposit fees: Shall be paid upon submittal of plans or request for
inspection and/or testing. The total final cost shall be the actual cost
incurred by the Municipality for administering and conducting the required
action (including, but not limited to reviews, inspections and testing). Any
balance remaining shall be refunded by the Municipality within sixty (60) days;
any charges in excess of deposit shall be paid within thirty (30) days of
receipt of invoice for same. No final Municipal approval for the subject
project shall be granted until all outstanding fees have been paid in full.
      (1)   The deposit for review of proposed utility work which is within the
scope of the Land Planning and Development Regulations shall be as is provided
for therein. The deposit for review of proposed utility work which is not
subject to said Regulations shall be one hundred ($100.00) dollars.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
      (2)   The construction inspection deposit for utility work which is
within the scope of the Land Planning and Development Regulations shall be
equal to ten (10%) percent of the estimated total cost of construction (not
including "prevailing wage') for all improvements requiring inspection
services. Excepting that the costs for inspections of utility service work for
a one or two-family residence are included in the permit fee amounts set forth
in subsection (a) above.
         (Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
      (3)   The work and materials testing deposit shall be one hundred (100%)
percent of the estimated costs for materials testing, plus testing of work
during, or after, construction, plus any acceptance tests or procedures
required for improvements to be dedicated to public use.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.19 APPEALS.
   If it is alleged that any order, requirement, decision or determination made
by the Authority having jurisdiction in the enforcement of the Public Utilities
Code is unreasonable or in error of law, then the aggrieved party may appeal
said order, requirement, decision or determination in accordance with the
provisions and procedures of Chapter
1119 (Appeals) of the Land Planning and Development Regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.30 PLANNING AND DESIGN.
   The planning and design of work within the scope of the Public Utilities
Code shall conform to the regulations contained herein; to the planning
principles set forth in Chapter
1150 and the general requirements for improvements set forth in Chapter
1151 of the Land Planning And Development Regulations; and all other applicable
Municipal requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.50 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
   All work within the scope of the Public Utilities Code shall conform to the
regulations contained herein; to the general requirements for improvements set
forth in Chapter
1151 of the Land Planning And Development Regulations; and all other applicable
Municipal requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY.
 
920.91 PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE.
   (a)   Any contractor, being any person, corporation or other entity,
proposing to do work involving any Municipal utility or proposing to do work
within any public right of way or easement shall furnish and file with the
Authority having jurisdiction a bond, to be approved as to form by the
Municipal Law Director, in the sum of five-thousand ($5000.00) dollars
guaranteeing full and faithful compliance with all provisions of the
ordinances, specifications and other requirements of the Municipality. Said
contractor shall further furnish evidence of liability insurance for bodily
injury in the minimum amount of one-hundred-thousand dollars/three-hundred-
thousand dollars ($100,000/ $300,000), and for property damage in the amount of
fifty-thousand ($50,000) dollars.
(Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
 
   (b)   Any developer proposing work within the scope of these regulations
shall be required to post performance guarantees, in accordance with the
provisions therefor set forth in Section
1151.91 (Performance Guarantees) of the Land Planning And Development
Regulations, and the following conditions.
      (1)   The Approving Authority for the subject project shall, without
exception, require performance guarantees for an improvement when any variance
is granted to any regulation herein governing said improvement (i.e. any
variance granted to the water regulations shall require a performance guarantee
for all water improvements in the project; variance granted to requirements of
this chapter shall require performance guarantee for all public utility
improvements regulated herein).
      (2)   When the Approving Authority for the subject project deems such
guarantees, for the improvements regulated-herein, to be necessary and
appropriate to the circumstances of the project so as to insure that public
funds of the Municipality shall not be expended in the event of failure (on the
part of any property owner, developer or contractor) to complete the required
improvements, then the guarantee shall be required.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.92 CONFORM TO APPROVED PLAN.
   Any work done within the scope of these regulations shall be in strict
conformance with the plans and specifications for same as approved by the
Municipality. Any deviation therefrom shall require the specific written
approval of the Approving Authority for the subject project.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.93 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   All work within the scope of these regulations shall be subject to
inspection by the Municipality for determination of conformance with the
approved plans, specifications, and applicable Municipal requirements. The work
and materials shall be subject to testing by the Municipality, as may be
appropriate in accordance with accepted engineering practice, for determination
of conformance with the specifications and applicable engineering standards.
The specific requirements for inspection and testing are set forth in the
following individual regulations. The cost of such inspections and testing
shall be paid by the developer in accordance with the requirements of section
920.18 (Schedule of Fees).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.94 MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE.
   The developer shall guarantee the materials and workmanship of all
improvements required within this code to be dedicated to public use, and
certain private improvements when so required by a specific improvement
regulation. Said maintenance guarantee shall be in accordance with the terms
and conditions set forth in Section
1151.94 (Maintenance Guarantee) of the Land Planning and Development
Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.95 FORFEITURE OF GUARANTEES.
   When performance, maintenance, or other guarantees have been posted and
thereafter the developer fails to diligently pursue the work; or fails to
complete the installation of the guaranteed improvements; or fails to construct
said improvements in accordance with the approved Construction Document
submittal; or otherwise fails to conform with any terms and/or conditions of
any Municipal approvals or Municipal requirements for the subject project, then
the Municipality, after giving notice which it deems reasonable under the
particular circumstances, shall utilize such monies or bonds as have been
posted.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
920.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of these regulation or fails to comply with
any order issued pursuant to these regulations shall be charged with, and
subject to the penalties for, the following:
      First offense: Minor misdemeanor.
      Second offense: Fourth degree misdemeanor.
      All offenses thereafter: First degree misdemeanor.
   Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)

CROSS REFERENCES
Manager - see ADM.
127
Water Regulations - see S.U. & P.S. Chapter
927 
Construction Inspection and testing - see S.U. & P.S.
920.93 
Street opening and boring - see Street Regulations
901.57
 
921.00 GENERAL.
 
921.01 SCOPE OF REGULATION.
   (a)   The water usage rates and other charges associated with Municipal
water services shall be as provided for herein.
 
   (b)   The terms and conditions under which the Municipality will provide
water service shall be as set forth in this regulation and Chapter
927 (Water Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
921.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   (a)   The Public Service Director shall be responsible for the
administration and enforcement of these regulations.
 
   (b)   The Finance director shall be responsible for the billing and
collection of the rates and charges set forth herein.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.12 PROPERTY OWNER LIABLE FOR CHARGES.
   The owners of real property installing or maintaining water services shall
be liable for all water charges incurred for services at such premises.
(Ord. 773. Passed 10-2-80.)
 
921.13 DECLARATION OF NECESSITY.
   It is hereby determined and declared to be necessary to the protection of
the public health, safety and welfare of the Municipality to establish and
collect water service charges and rates upon all lots, lands and premises
served by connection with the Municipal water system, as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.14 DISPOSITION OF FUNDS.
   (a)   The funds received from the collection of TAP-IN FEES provided for in
Section
921.162, and such other fees and charges as may be designated by Council, shall
be deposited as received by the Finance Director, who shall keep the same in a
separate fund designated WATER TAP-IN FUND. Subject to the provisions of any
ordinance or indenture of mortgage authorizing and securing the issuance of
mortgage revenue bonds for the water system, moneys in the fund shall be used
for capital improvements for the water system and works, and such other
purposes permitted by R.C. § 743.05 and the Constitution of the State.
 
   (b)   The funds received from the collection of WATER USAGE RATES provided
for in Section
921.17 et seq., and such other fees and charges as may be designated by
Council, shall be deposited as received by the Finance Director, who shall keep
the same in a separate fund designated WATER OPERATING FUND. Subject to the
provisions of any ordinance or indenture of mortgage authorizing and securing
the issuance of mortgage revenue bonds for the water system, moneys in the fund
shall be used for the payment of the cost and expense of the operation,
maintenance, repair and management of the water system, and for the payment of
debt charges on bonds issued for extensions and improvements of the system. Any
surplus in the fund over and above the requirements before mentioned may be
used for the enlargement and replacement of the water system and works, and
such other purposes permitted by R.C. § 743.05 and the Constitution of the
State.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.15 ANNUAL REVIEW.
   All water charges set forth herein shall be reviewed annually by Council, or
its designate, in order to determine whether or not they are sufficient to
defray the fixed charges, amortization costs and annual cost of operation of
the water distribution system, and the cost of municipal service provided in
association therewith. If the difference between the total annual revenue
derived and the total annual cost is sufficient to justify an increase or
decrease in the water rates and/or charges, said rates and/or charges will be
adjusted as required.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.16 WATER CHARGES.
 
921.161 APPLICATION DEPOSIT.
   (a)   Upon application for a permit for work within the scope of Chapter
927 (Water Regulations), or an application for water service, the applicant
shall deposit a sum set by the Authority having jurisdiction to cover all costs
provided for in these regulations, which shall be accrued by the Municipality.
Any costs accrued by the Municipality in excess of the deposit shall be paid by
the applicant prior to the Municipality granting final approval of the work.
Any amount left from such deposit shall be returned within sixty days of the
Municipality's final approval of the work.
 
   (b)   For the purpose of this section the fees and charges set forth in
Section
921.16 et seq. are cumulative, unless specifically otherwise noted.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.162 TAP-IN FEES.
   A fee shall be levied for each user connection (whether direct or indirect)
and any direct tap for the extension of existing water mains based on the size
of the service lateral or water main connected to the water system in
accordance with the following schedule and requirements.
   (a)   Tap-in fee schedule:
 
Line Size (inches)      Charge
   ¾         $1475.00
   1         1500.00
   1-½         1575.00
   2         1675.00
   3         1750.00
   4         1875.00
   6         2125.00
   8         2375.00
   12         2875.00
   16         3375.00
 
(Ord. 1262. Passed 02-08-90.)
   (b)   The tap-in fee for a single tenant building shall be the sum of
charges for each service lateral installed to said building.
   (c)   The tap-in fee for a multi-tenant buildings shall be-the sum of
charges for the size of service provided to each tenant area plus the size of
service provided for general building use.
   (d)   Construction projects which include the installation of new water
mains shall be charged for each direct tap (except as otherwise provided for
herein). In projects with multiple construction phases, a tap-in fee shall be
charged for the extension of each water main to serve a new construction phase.
      (1)   The Authority having jurisdiction shall waive the charge for a
direct tap for a new water main within a specific construction project phase,
when said tap and new mains will actually grid the municipal water system (see
Section
927.55(b); Water Regulations).
      (2)   No tap fee shall be charged for improvements required to be
installed under Section
927.56 (Provide for Future Connections). However, when application is made for
the continuation of service from such connections the applicant there for shall
pay the required tap-in fee in effect at the time of said application.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91)
 
921.163 STREET OPENING AND BORING.
   In addition to the fees set forth herein the applicant for water service
shall pay such fees and deposit as may be set forth in Chapter
901 (Street Regulation) for the opening, boring and/or restoration of streets
when such work is necessarily associated with any work within the scope of
Chapter
927 (Water Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.164 CHARGES FOR MUNICIPAL WORK.
   When the provisions of Chapter
927 (Water Regulations) require that certain work be done by the Municipality,
the applicant for water service shall be charged for said work. The charge
shall be equal to the Municipality's total cost for all labor, material and
equipment usage to do the required work plus thirty percent (30%) of said total
costs.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.165 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   All costs associated with the inspection, supervision and testing of any
water service improvement or service installation shall be paid by the
applicant for water service in accordance with the requirements set forth in
Section
920.18 (Schedule of Fees) of the Public Utilities Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.166 WATER METER CHARGES.
   (a)   The applicant for water service shall be charged for each water meter,
remote meter reading device and any other associated materials, services or
work which may be furnished by the Municipality.
      (1)   The charge for materials shall be the Municipality's total cost for
all meters, remote reading devices, meter ball valves and any other materials
which may be furnished, plus thirty percent (30%) of said total cost.
      (2)   When the installation of water meters is required to be done by the
Municipality there shall be an additional charge for the installation work as
set forth in §
921.164  (Charge For Municipal Work).
 
   (b)   A service charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be made for
testing water meters when said testing is done under the provisions of §
927.81  of the Water Regulations.
      (1)   Should testing show that the water meter does not meet the required
standards, said meter shall be replaced at no cost to the property owner.
However, should testing show that the water meter is within the required
standards an additional charge, as set forth in §
921.164  (Charges For Municipal Work), shall be made for re-installing the
meter.
      (2)   The charges set forth in this section shall be added to the water
bill and collected in the same manner as other water bill charges.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.167 CONSTRUCTION WATER SERVICE.
   Upon application for a construction water service the applicant shall pay a
security deposit for the water meter and shall further pay a flat fee for water
usage. The deposit shall be returned to the applicant if the meter is returned
in good condition.
   (a)   The security deposit shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00).
   (b)   The flat fee for water usage shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00).
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.168 TURN-ON CHARGE.
   If the Water is turned off to any premises at the request of the owner or
possessor for any reason whatsoever not caused by an action of the City of
Chardon, Ohio, then the possessor and/or owner shall pay a fee of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) prior to the water being turned on again to said premises.
(Ord. 1217. Passed 04-13-89.)
 
921.169 POOL METER CHARGE.
   A charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be made for each use and
installation of a pool meter by the Municipality. The account of the dwelling,
building or structure shall receive a sewer credit for the amount of water
measured by the pool meter at the rate set forth in §
923.172 (a)(1).
(Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
921.17 WATER USAGE RATES.
 
921.171 RATES BASED ON METER READINGS.
   Except as provided otherwise, all water rates shall be based upon an actual
consumption basis as appears from the tabulation of the meter reading.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.172 RATES INSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)    The prices to be charged for water furnished to all consumers
situated in the Municipality shall be as follows:

(Ord. 3154. Passed 2-11-21.)
   (b)    The water rates in subsection (a) correspond to the billing/
collections period for each calendar year.
   (c)    Water rates shall be billed monthly and charged to the property
owner.
(Ord. 2735. Passed 9-13-12.)
   (d)    (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former subsection (d) was repealed by Ordinance 3154,
passed February 11, 2021.)
   (e)   Under the utility discount program, a ratepayer who is a senior
citizen or is disabled and whose household income is less than or equal to
$40,037 per year ("ratepayer") shall be given a reduction in the amount of each
monthly residential water bill pursuant to the income guidelines and credits
set forth below.
      (1)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of less than $20,019,
the ratepayer shall be given a credit of 40% of the amount of each monthly
water bill.
      (2)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of at least $20,019 but
less than or equal to $26,691, the ratepayer shall be given a credit of 35% of
the amount of each monthly water bill.
      (3)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of at least $26,691.01
but less than or equal to $33,364, the ratepayer shall be given a credit of 30%
of the amount of each monthly water bill.
      (4)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of at least $33,364.01
but less than or equal to $40,037, the ratepayer shall be given a credit of 25%
of the amount of each monthly water bill.
         (Ord. 3211. Passed 8-11-22.)
   (f)    A "disabled consumer" is an owner or renter of the residential
premises which receives water service and who has been determined to be
disabled by the Social Security Administration or a State of Ohio retirement
system; permanently and totally disabled by the Bureau of Workers'
Compensation; or who presents evidence of disability satisfactory to the
Finance Director and Law Director.
   (g)    When necessary, the above rates shall be adjusted to correspond to
the consumer's meter reading system. (Ord. 2735. Passed 9-13-12.)
 
921.173 RATES OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)   The price to be charged for water furnished by the Water Department to
all consumers situated outside the municipal limits after November 20, 1990
shall be the rate fixed under §
921.172 (a) of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Chardon, plus a 20%
percent surcharge thereon. This rate is only applied to users now being served
outside the municipal boundaries of the City of Chardon. No other water service
shall be provided nor service enlarged to any person or user not within said
municipal boundaries.
 
   (b)   Water rates shall be billed monthly and charged to the property owner.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
921.174 WATER CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FEE.
   (a)   There is hereby levied and assessed upon each water customer a

921.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY
 
921.901 DELINQUENT ACCOUNT ACTIONS.
   (a)   Lien and Certification. Each water charge levied pursuant to this
chapter is made a lien upon the corresponding lot, parcel of land, building or
premises, which is served by a connection to the water system of the
municipality. If the account is delinquent for more than thirty days, the
Finance Director may certify such amount due to the County Auditor, at which
time the lien shall vest. The County Auditor shall place the same on the tax
duplicate of the county together with the interest and penalties as provided by
this chapter and cause such amount to be collected as other Municipal taxes are
collected.
(Ord. 773. Passed 10-2-80.)
 
   (b)   Water Shutoff. In addition to the certification to the County Auditor
as provided herein, the Finance Director is hereby authorized to and may, if
the water charge has not been paid more than thirty days from the date it
becomes due and payable, direct the Public Service Director to shut off water
service to those premises for which amounts are due until the outstanding water
charges have been paid.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
   (c)   Water Turn On Charge. When the water is turned off for nonpayment of
charges, a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be made for turning on
the water. However, all amounts due shall be paid in full before the water will
be turned on again.
(Ord. 1217. Passed 04-13-89.)
 
   (d)   Penalty On Delinquent Accounts. Any water bills not paid within
twenty-one days of the invoice date shall be subject to a six percent (6%)
penalty to be added to the total delinquent bill. If the due date falls on a
holiday, payment on the next business day shall not be delinquent. (Ord. 1327
Passed 5-9-91)
(Ord. 2003. Passed 9-7-00.)

Untreated sewage - see R.C. § 3701.59

923.00 GENERAL.
 
923.01 SCOPE OF REGULATION.
   (a)   The sanitary sewer service rates and other charges associated with
Municipal sanitary sewerage system services shall be as provided for in this
chapter.
 
   (b)   The terms and conditions under which the Municipality provides
sanitary sewerage system service shall be as set forth in this Chapter and
Chapter
925  (Sanitary Sewer Regulations) and such Industrial Waste Discharge
regulations as may be adopted by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
923.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   (a)   The Public Service Director shall be responsible for the
administration and enforcement of this regulation.
 
   (b)   The Finance Director shall be responsible for the billing and
collection of the rates and charges set forth herein.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.12 PROPERTY OWNER LIABLE FOR CHARGES.
   The owners of real property installing or maintaining sewer services shall
be liable for all sewer charges incurred for services at such premises.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.13 DECLARATION OF NECESSITY.
   It is hereby determined and declared to be necessary to the protection of
the public health, safety and welfare of the Municipality to establish and
collect sewer service charges upon all lots, lands and premises served by
connection with the sanitary sewerage system, as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 422. Passed 12-2-65.)
 
923.14 DISPOSITION OF FUNDS.
   (a)   The funds received from the collection of sanitary sewer TAP-IN FEES,
and such other fees and charges as may be designated by Council, shall be
deposited as received by the Finance Director, who shall keep the same in a
separate fund designated SEWER TAP-IN FUND. Subject to the provisions of any
ordinance or indenture of mortgage authorizing and securing the issuance of
mortgage revenue bonds for the sewerage system, moneys in the fund shall be
used for capital improvements for the system and works, and such other purposes
permitted by R.C. § 729.52 and the Constitution of the State.
 
   (b)   The funds received from the collection of sanitary sewer USAGE RATES
provided for in Section
923.17 et seq., and such other fees and charges as may be designated by
Council, shall be deposited as received by the Finance Director, who shall keep
the same in a separate fund designated SEWER OPERATING FUND. Subject to the
provisions of any ordinance or indenture of mortgage authorizing and securing
the issuance of mortgage revenue bonds for the sewerage system, moneys in the
fund shall be used for the payment of the cost and expense of the operation,
maintenance, repair and management of the system, and for the payment of debt
charges on bonds issued for extensions and improvements of the system. Any
surplus in the fund over and above the requirements before mentioned may be
used for the enlargement and replacement of the sewerage system and works, and
such other purposes permitted by R.C. § 729.52 and the Constitution of the
State.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2124. Passed 7-11-02.)
 
923.15 ANNUAL REVIEW.
   The sewer service charge and surcharges shall be reviewed annually by the
Municipality in order to determine whether or not they are sufficient to defray
the fixed charges, amortization costs and annual cost of the operation of the
sewerage system as determined from the wastewater treatment plant records. If
the difference between the total annual revenue derived and the total annual
cost is sufficient to justify an increase or decrease in the sewer service
charge or surcharge, the Municipality will adjust the rates as required.
(Ord. 749. Passed 4-30-80.)
 
923.16 SANITARY SEWER CHARGES.
 
923.161 APPLICATION DEPOSIT.
   (a)   Upon application for a permit for work within the scope of Chapter
925  (Sanitary Sewer Regulations), or an application for sanitary sewer
service, the applicant shall deposit a sum set by the Authority having
jurisdiction to cover all costs provided for in these regulations, which shall
be accrued by the Municipality. Any costs accrued by the Municipality in excess
of the deposit shall be paid by the applicant prior to the Municipality
granting final approval of the work. Any amount left from such deposit shall be
returned within sixty days of the Municipality's final approval of the work.
 
   (b)   For the purpose of this section the fees and charges set forth in §§
923.16  et seq. are cumulative, unless specifically otherwise noted.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.162 TAP-IN FEES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section
923.162 was repealed by Ordinance 2124, passed July 11, 2002)
 
923.163 STREET OPENING AND BORING.
   In addition to the fees set forth herein the applicant for sewer service
shall pay such fees and deposit as are set forth in §
900.18  (Street and Sidewalk Code) for the opening, boring and/or restoration
of streets when such work is necessarily associated with any work within the
scope of Chapter
925  (Sanitary Sewer Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.164 CHARGES FOR MUNICIPAL WORK.
   When the provisions of Chapter
925  (Sanitary Sewer Regulations) require that certain work be done by the
Municipality, the applicant for sanitary sewerage service shall be charged for
said work. The charge shall be equal to the Municipality's total cost for all
labor, material and equipment usage to do the required work plus thirty percent
(30%) of said total costs.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.165 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   All costs associated with the inspection, supervision and testing of any
water service improvement or service installation shall be paid by the
applicant for sewer service in accordance with the requirements set forth in §
920.18 (Schedule of Fees) of the Public Utilities Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.166 SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT CHARGES BILLED AND COLLECTED MONTHLY.
   In addition to the fees set forth in this Chapter
923, the applicant for sanitary sewer service is required to pay the system
development charge (SDC) imposed by Chapter
1157 C.O., a proportionate share of the cost for expansion of the waste water
treatment plant which is a permanent improvement necessary to conduct and
manage the waterworks of the Municipality. (See §743.04 O.R.C.) The amount, if
any, which is not paid when the zoning permit is issued shall be billed and
collected pursuant to Section
 923.11 and shall be a sanitary sewer charge pursuant to this Chapter
923 and Section
923.901.
(Ord. 2742. Passed 9-13-12.)
 
923.17 SANITARY SEWER USAGE RATES.
 
923.171 RATES BASED ON WATER METER READINGS.
   Except as provided otherwise, all sewer rates shall be based upon an actual
water consumption basis as appears from the tabulation of the water meter
reading.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)

   (d)   Under the utility discount program, a ratepayer who is a senior

      (1)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of less than $20,019,

      (2)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of at least $20,019 but

      (3)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of at least $26,691.01

of the amount of each monthly sewer bill.
      (4)   If a ratepayer has annual household income of at least $33,364.01

of the amount of each monthly sewer bill.
         (Ord. 3211. Passed 8-11-22.)
   (e)    A "disabled consumer" is an owner or renter of the residential

Compensation; or who presents evidence of disability satisfactory to the
Finance Director and Law Director.
   (f)   When necessary, the above rates shall be adjusted to correspond to the
consumer's meter reading system. (Ord. 2736. Passed 9-13-12.)
 
923.173 RATES OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   (a)   There is hereby levied and assessed upon each lot, parcel of land or
premises outside the corporate limits of the Municipality and having any active
sewer connection with the sanitary sewerage system of the Municipality, or
otherwise discharging sewerage, industrial waste, water or other liquids,
either directly or indirectly into such system or any part thereof, a service
charge and surcharge payable as provided in this chapter and in the amount
determinable as follows.
 
   (b)   The rate to be charged users outside the corporate limits shall be the
rates as are set forth in §
923.172  plus an additional 20% charge thereon. This rate shall only apply to
users now being served outside the municipal boundaries of the City of Chardon.
No other sewer service shall be provided, nor service enlarged, to any persons
not within said municipal boundaries.
 
   (c)   The charges set above shall be billed monthly and charged to the
property owner.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
923.174 CHARGES EXCLUSIVE OF VILLAGE WATER.
   (a)   In the event a lot, parcel, building or premises discharging sanitary
sewerage, industrial waste, water or other liquids into the Municipality's
sanitary sewerage system, either directly or indirectly, obtains part or all of
the water used from other sources than the City water system, which is not
measured by a water meter or is measured by a water meter not acceptable to the
Manager then, in such case, the owner or other interested party shall satisfy
the Manager as to a fair method of determining the sanitary sewerage used, or
upon failure to do so, each such owner or interested party shall, at his
expense, install and maintain meters, satisfactory to the Manager on all
supplies other than City water and the quantity of water used to determine the
sewerage charge shall be the sum of the quantities of water measured by all
such meters.
(Ord. 867. Passed 3-3-83.)
 
   (b)   In the event a lot, parcel of land, building or premises discharges
into the sanitary sewerage system, either directly or indirectly, and uses
water in excess of the amount allowed for a minimum bill per month, and it can
be shown, to the satisfaction of the Manager, that a portion of the Water as
measured by the water meter does not and cannot enter the sanitary sewerage
system, then the Manager may determine, in such manner and by such method as he
may find practicable, the percentage of metered water entering the sanitary
sewerage system, or the Manager may require or permit the installation of
additional meters in such a manner as to determine the quantity of water
actually entering the sewerage system, subject to the minimum charge provisions
of Sections
923.172 and
923.173.
(Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
 
923.175 SURCHARGES.
   (a)   Upgrade Surcharge: There is hereby levied and assessed upon each lot,
parcel of land and premises within the corporate limits and having any active
sewer connection with the sanitary sewerage system of the Municipality on or
before April 20, 1993, or otherwise discharging sewerage, industrial waste,
water or other liquids, either directly or indirectly into such system or any
part thereof, an Upgrade Surcharge payable as provided in this section and in
the amount determinable as follows:
      (1)   Surcharge for upgrade improvements: This surcharge is a
proportionate share of the cost of the 1999 waste water treatment plant
upgrades. The surcharge relates to the plant upgrade improvements set forth in
the 1996 Sanitary Sewer Evaluation Study (or as thereafter adjusted and/or
modified by City Council); and the cost to finance those improvements. The
total upgrade surcharge, over the life of the financing term, reflects existing
users' full proportionate share of the 1999 waste water treatment plant project
costs.
      (2)   Monthly charge: This surcharge shall be in addition to the other
rates and charges provided for in this chapter. This surcharge shall be a
recurring monthly charge billed and payable as part of the regular monthly
water and sewer billing. The Upgrade Surcharge shall continue until all costs
associated with the 1999 waste water treatment plant upgrades have been paid.
(Ord. 2737. Passed 9-13-12.)
      (3)   Rate: This surcharge shall be updated and billed at the following
rates:
Upgrade Surcharge, Excluding Commercial and Industrial Consumers
 
                         2013  2014  2015  2016  2017  2018  2019  2020  2021
0 to First 1,000 Gallons $2.32 $2.32 $2.32 $2.32 $2.32 $2.32 $2.62 $2.62 $2.62
Used
Per 100 Gallons Used     $0.24 $0.24 $0.24 $0.24 $0.24 $0.24 $0.27 $0.27 $0.27
Thereafter

                         2013  2014  2015  2016  2017  2018  2019  2020  2021

Used
Per 100 Gallons Used     $0.28 $0.28 $0.28 $0.28 $0.28 $0.28 $0.32 $0.32 $0.32
Thereafter
      (4)   The surcharges in subsection (a)(3) correspond to the billing/
collections period for each calendar year. The surcharges will cease on June
30, 2021, when the last payment of the debt for the wastewater treatment plant
is scheduled to be made.
      (5)   When necessary, the above rates shall be adjusted to correspond to
the consumer's meter reading system.
      (6)   Use of upgrade surcharge:  
         A.   All funds collected shall be directly credited to the Water
Pollution Control Loan Fund Capital Improvement Fund ("WPCLF Capital
Improvement Fund") and used solely for the purposes identified in this
Ordinance.
         B.   Funds collected as upgrade surcharges shall be used only for
payment of waste water treatment plant upgrades.
         C.   Funds shall be construed as being expended in the order in which
they are collected, in accordance with "First-In First-Out" principles.
         D.   In each fiscal period the Finance Director shall present to the
City Council an annual report, describing the amount of upgrade surcharges
collected, encumbered and used during the preceding year. Balances collected,
including any accrued interest not encumbered in any fiscal period, shall be
retained in the same WPCLF Capital Improvement Fund until the next fiscal
period.
         E.   The upgrade surcharges shall be used, first, to retire WPCLF loan
debt service which is pending for the year in which the upgrade surcharges were
collected and which the City incurred to provide the waste water and treatment
plant upgrades that accommodate existing development; second, to reimburse
other accounts from which funds to finance WPCLF debt service were advanced;
and, third, to pay other upgrade construction costs which are pending and which
costs the City incurred, to provide waste water and treatment plant upgrades
that accommodate existing development.
   (b)   Water Treatment Plant Surcharge: There is hereby levied and assessed
upon each water consumer a surcharge to help fund the debt for the water
treatment plant, as follows:

until all related debt costs have been paid.
      (3)   When necessary, the above rates shall be adjusted to correspond to
the consumer's meter reading system.
      (4)   Use of funds:
         A.   All funds collected shall be directly credited to the Water Debt
Surcharge Account within the WSRLA Debt Service Fund, and used solely for the
purposes identified in this section.
         B.   Funds collected shall be used only for payment of the water
treatment plant debt.
         C.   Funds shall be construed as being expended in the order in which
they are collected, in accordance with "First-In First-Out" principles.
         D.   In each fiscal period the Finance Director shall present to the
City Council an annual report, describing the amount of surcharges collected,
encumbered and used during the preceding year. Balances collected, including
any accrued interest not encumbered in any fiscal period, shall be retained in
the WSRLA Debt Service Fund until the next fiscal period.
         E.   The surcharges shall be used, first, to retire water treatment
plant debt service which is pending for the year in which the surcharges were
collected; and second, to reimburse other accounts from which funds to finance
water treatment plant debt service were advanced.

      (1)   The eastside trunk surcharges in subsection (c) correspond to the
billing/collections period for each calendar year and shall cease after the

      (2)   Monthly charge: This surcharge shall be in addition to the other
rates and charges provided for in this chapter. This surcharge shall be a
recurring monthly charge billed and payable as part of the normal monthly water
and sewer billing. The Eastside Trunk Sewer Surcharge shall continue until all
related debt costs have been paid.
      (3)   When necessary, the above rates shall be adjusted to correspond to
the consumer's meter reading system.
      (4)   Use of funds:  
         A.   All funds collected shall be directly credited to the Eastside
Trunk Surcharge Account within the WPCLF Debt Service Fund, and used solely for
the purposes identified in this section.
         B.   Funds collected shall be used only for payment of the eastside
trunk sewer debt.
         C.   Funds shall be construed as being expended in the order in which
they are collected, in accordance with "First-In First-Out" principles.
         D.   In each fiscal period the Finance Director shall present to the
City Council an annual report, describing the amount of surcharges collected,
encumbered and used during the preceding year. Balances collected, including
any accrued interest not encumbered in any fiscal period, shall be retained in
the WPCLF Debt Service Fund until the next fiscal period.
         E.   The surcharges shall be used, first, to retire eastside trunk
sewer debt service which is pending for the year in which the surcharges were
collected; and second, to reimburse other accounts from which funds to finance
eastside trunk sewer debt service were advanced.
   (d)   Surcharge for Sewage or Wastes above Normal Sewage Levels. Sewage or
industrial wastes above normal sewage levels but acceptable for discharge into
the sanitary sewerage system shall be subject to a surcharge. The surcharge
shall be determined based on the amount of any, or all, of the following
constituents of the water or waste which are in excess of the limits prescribed
for each in the definition of normal sewage:
      Total suspended solids; and/or
      B.O.D.; and/or
      Phosphorus; and/or
      Ammonia-nitrogen
   The surcharge provided for herein shall be in addition to the other rates
and charges provided for in this chapter. The pounds of B.O.D. per day, pounds
of suspended solids per day, pounds of phosphorus per day, and pounds of
ammonia-nitrogen per day, above the concentration previously described for
normal sewage levels that are discharged to the sewerage system, shall be
determined by the Municipality or an authorized representative.
   (e)   Additional Surcharge. In addition to the surcharges described herein,
the Municipality shall have and reserves the right to surcharge any user for
the discharge of any pollutant into the sewage system or for any other reason
that it deems necessary and appropriate.
(Ord. 2737. Passed 9-13-12.)

a multiple tenant building.

923.56 TAP-IN FEE, USER CONNECTION PRIVILEGE FEE; PAYMENT.
   (a)   A "tap-in fee" for lots or parcels of record on the date of enactment
of this section (permanent parcel numbers 10-003800, 10-020350, 10-082380, 10-
084080, 10-087301, 10-162000, 10-005261, 10-003801, 10-036050, and 10-164722)
shall be paid on or before June 8, 2003 or on the date of application for any
permit required under the Codified Ordinances to connect a structure to the
sanitary sewer line, whichever shall first occur.
 
   (b)   A "user connection privilege fee" for vacant lots or parcels of record
on the date of this ordinance [permanent parcel nos. (Ash) (Jones) (River
Oaks)] and for lots or parcels which may hereafter be split from the ten
parcels with permanent parcel numbers listed herein or in subsection (a) above
comprising the Claridon Road Sanitary Sewer District No. 1 shall be paid within
one year from the date that the Minor Subdivision, Major Subdivision, or PUD
plat is filed for record in the Office of the Geauga County Recorder or on the
date of application for any permit required under the Codified Ordinances to
connect a structure to the sanitary sewer line, whichever shall first occur.
 
   (c)   The owner of a lot or parcel shall not be required to pay a tap-in fee
if a user connection privilege fee has previously been paid for that parcel or
lot.
 
   (d)   As used in this section, the word "fee" shall mean a "tap-in fee" or
"user connection privilege fee."
(Ord. 2115. Passed 5-9-02; Ord. 2128. Passed 8-8-02.)
 
923.57 USE OF FEES.
   All fees collected for present or future connection to the Claridon Road
sanitary sewer line shall be used exclusively for reimbursement of the Sewer
Operating Fund from which funds were used to pay for construction of the
Claridon Road sanitary sewer line in the Claridon Road Sanitary Sewer District
No. 1.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 5-9-02; Ord. 2128. Passed 8-8-02.)
 
923.58 TERMINATION OF FEE.
   The fee shall remain in effect until the cost of construction of the
Claridon Road Sanitary Sewer Extension Project, plus the loss of use of the
funds by the Municipality at the rate of four percent (4%) per annum, is paid.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 5-9-02; Ord. 2128. Passed 8-8-02.)
 
923.59 OTHER FEES.
   All other fees and charges imposed by the Codified Ordinances for connection
to the municipal sanitary sewer system shall be applicable to the development
of any parcel within the Claridon Road Sanitary Sewer District No. 1 and in
addition to the fee charged herein.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 5-9-02; Ord. 2128. Passed 8-8-02.)
 
923.60 REZONING.
   A condition for rezoning to a non-residential use or granting a variance for
a non-residential use shall be the calculation of the fee(s) for such use.
(Ord. 2115. Passed 5-9-02; Ord. 2128. Passed 8-8-02.)
 
923.70 WILSON MILLS SERVICE AREA (SW5).
 
923.71 CREATION OF A SPECIAL SANITARY SEWER SERVICE AREA.
   Council hereby creates and establishes a special service area within the
Southwest Sanitary Sewer District to be known as the "Wilson Mills Service Area
(SW2)".
(Ord. 2602. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.72 REAL PROPERTY COMPRISING THE WILSON MILLS SERVICE AREA.

parcels of real property included in the Wilson Mills Service Area (SW5) of the
Southwest Sanitary Sewer District, including any parcels which may hereafter be
consolidated or split therefrom, whether approved pursuant to the Codified
Ordinances as a Major Subdivision, Minor Subdivision, Lot Split or Planned Unit
Development.

923.73 PROJECT PLANS.
   The City Engineer shall cause plans for Wilson Mills Road Sanitary Sewer
Project to be on file with the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 2602. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.74 TIME LIMIT FOR CONNECTION.
   The owner of a parcel within the Wilson Mills Service Area with a building
thereon that generates sewage and which is located 200 feet or less from the
Wilson Mills Road easement or right-of-way, shall install an approved
connection to the Wilson Mills Sanitary Sewer in compliance with the Codified
Ordinances of the City of Chardon no later than November 30, 2012.
(Ord. 2602. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.75 LEVY OF TAP-IN FEE.
   (a) A fee shall be levied for each user connection (whether direct or
indirect) within the Wilson Mills Service Area (SW5).
   (b) A "user connection", for which a fee is levied, is a connection to the
sanitary sewer of a single family residence or single tenant building, a
dwelling unit in a duplex or multiple family dwelling and each tenant space in
a multiple tenant building.
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.76 AMOUNT OF FEE.
   The amount of the fee shall be $598.00 until December 31, 2012. Thereafter,
the amount of the fee shall be increased on January 1 of each year by four
percent (4%) per annum, compounded annually.
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.77 “TAP-IN FEE”; PAYMENT.
   A "tap-in fee" is imposed upon lots or parcels within the Wilson Mills
Service Area (SW5) as identified in Ordinance #2602 (AN ORDINANCE AMENDING
CHAPTER 923 OF THE CODIFIED ORDINANCES CREATING THE WILSON MILLS SERVICE AREA
(SW5) OF THE SOUTHWEST SANITARY SEWER DISTRICT, A SPECIAL SANITARY SEWER
SERVICE AREA; REQUIRING PROPERTY OWNERS TO CONNECT TO THE SANITARY SEWER, AND
DECLARING AN EMERGENCY) and for lots or parcels which may hereafter be
consolidated or split from the parcels listed therein whether approved pursuant
to the Codified Ordinances as a Major Subdivision, Minor Subdivision, Lot Split
or Planned Unit Development. The tap-in fee shall be paid on the date of
application for a permit required under the Codified Ordinances to connect a
structure to the sanitary sewer line.
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.78 USE OF FEES.
   Tap-in fees collected for connection to the Wilson Mills Sanitary Sewer
shall be used exclusively for reimbursement of the Sewer Operating Fund from
which funds were used to pay for construction of the Wilson Mills Sanitary
Sewer Project, City Project 03-43, in the Wilson Mills Service Area (SW5).
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.79 TERMINATION OF FEE.
   The fee shall remain in effect until the cost of construction of the Wilson
Mills Sanitary Sewer Project, City Project 03-43, and the amount equal to the
loss of use of the funds by the Municipality at the rate of four percent (4%)
per annum to pay for the project is recovered.
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.80 OTHER CONNECTION FEES.
   Other fees and charges imposed pursuant to the Codified Ordinances for
connection to the municipal sanitary sewer system in addition to the tap-in fee
charged herein shall be applicable to the development of any parcel within the
Wilson Mills Service Area (SW5).
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
923.81 REZONING; USE VARIANCE.
   A condition for rezoning to a non-residential use or granting a variance for
a non-residential use shall be the calculation of the fee(s) for such use.
(Ord. 2603. Passed 8-12-10.)
 
923.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY.
 
923.901 DELINQUENT ACCOUNT ACTIONS.
   (a)   Charges are a lien. Each sewer charge levied pursuant to this Chapter
is hereby made a lien upon the premises charged therewith. If the account is
delinquent for more than thirty days, the Finance Director may certify the
amount due for the sewer charge to the County Auditor. The County Auditor shall
place the same on the tax duplicate of the County together with the interest
and penalties as provided by this Chapter, and cause such amount to be
collected as other Municipal taxes are collected.
 
   (b)   Discontinuance of Water Service. In addition to the certification to
the County Auditor as provided herein, the Finance Director is hereby
authorized to and may, after the sewer charge has not been paid more than
thirty days from the date it becomes due and payable, direct the Public Service
Director to shut off water service to those premises for which amounts are due
until the outstanding unpaid sewer charge and all penalties and interest
thereon have been fully paid.
 
   (c)   Water Turn On Charge. When the water is turned off for nonpayment of
charges, a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be made for turning on
the water. However, all amounts due shall be paid in full before the water will
be turned on again.
(Ord. 1217. Passed 04-13-89.)
 
   (d)   Penalty On Delinquent Accounts. Any sewer bills not paid within
twenty-one days of the invoice date shall be subject to a six percent (6%)
penalty to be added to the total delinquent sewer bill. If the due date falls
on a holiday, payment on the next business day shall not be delinquent.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
(Ord. 2003. Passed 9-7-00.)
