925.00 GENERAL.
 
925.01 SCOPE OF REGULATIONS.
   The construction, reconstruction, alteration, extension or excavation of any
part of the Municipal sanitary sewer system; or any connection thereto; or the
use of, or the discharge of any substance into, said system shall be in
accordance with these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
925.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   The Public Service Director shall be responsible for the administration and
enforcement of this regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.12 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   A sanitary sewer work permit shall be required for all work within the
scope of this regulation. The permit requirements shall be the same as are set
forth in Section
920.12.
 
   (b)   No permits for building construction shall be issued for any lot or
lands, for which Municipal sanitary sewer service is required, until a sewer
work permit has been issued by the Municipality.
 
   (c)   Every person, firm or corporation desiring sanitary sewer service
shall first make written application to the Authority having jurisdiction, or
his designate, on a blank furnished for that purpose. Such application shall be
signed by the owners of such property or their duly authorized agent. The
Authority having jurisdiction may require such addition information as is
necessary to insure conformance with, or provide for the enforcement of, all
applicable Municipal regulations and requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.13 PROJECT SUBMITTAL PROCEDURE; RECORD DRAWINGS.
   (a)   The submittal procedures for proposed sanitary sewer work shall be the
same as are set forth in Section
920.13.
      (1)   When proposed sewer lines are not part of another project, the
submittal shall be in accordance with the requirements for Lands For Public Use
when the work will be dedicated to public use; or the requirements for single
building site development when the work is for a private sewer line.
      (2)   The Municipal engineer's review and approval shall include, but is
not necessarily limited to, system design, sewer grade, location, capacity and
specifications. Copies of all design calculations shall be submitted for review
by, and shall be subject to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer.
 
   (b)   Record drawing for sanitary sewer work shall be required. The
requirements shall be the same as are set forth in Section
920.13.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.14 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Manager shall make and enforce such rules and regulations as he deems
necessary for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, the safe,
economical and efficient management and protection of the system, and for the
proper determination and collection of sewer charges. Such rules and
regulations shall have the same force and effect as ordinances when not
repugnant thereto or to State laws.
(Ord. 422. Passed 12-2-65.)
 
925.15 CONTRACT SERVICES.
   (a)   The Municipality, through it's Manager, shall have the right to
contract with any person or industry for sewerage service, including waste of
unusual strength or character, subject to the rates and provisions set forth in
this Chapter
923  (Sanitary Sewer Charges) and any limitations on strength of sewage and
other provisions of such Industrial Waste Discharges Regulation as may be
adopted by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
   (b)   The Manager shall determine which sampling tests (B.O.D., etc.), are
representative of actual wastewater loading and specify the type and frequency
of analysis necessary for monitoring discharges and billing purposes.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.30 PLANNING AND DESIGN.
 
925.31 DESIGN STANDARDS.
   Proposed sanitary sewer lines shall be planned, designed and constructed in
accordance with these regulations and as required by the Land Planning and
Development Regulations, Comprehensive Plan, Municipal Wastewater Collection
System Plan, accepted engineering practices and standards, Municipal Standard
Specifications For Sanitary Sewers and such other adopted regulations and
master plans of the Municipality as may be applicable.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.32 MUNICIPAL SPECIFICATION.
   All sanitary sewer service lines (whether public or private) shall be
constructed in accordance with the Municipal Standard Specification for
Sanitary Sewers.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.33 EASEMENTS AND RIGHTS OF WAY.
   When sanitary sewers proposed to be dedicated to public use are not located
within a dedicated street right of way, the developer shall grant a utility
easement or right of way to the Municipality, for the purpose of operating,
maintaining, enlarging, repairing, replacing, removing, relocating or adding
municipal utilities. Said easement or right of way width shall be equal to
twice the depth of the sewer plus ten (10) feet or thirty (30) feet in width,
whichever is greater, or as otherwise required by the Approving Authority. The
sanitary sewer shall be located inside the easement at a distance equal to one-
half (½) the depth of the sewer or at such other depth required by the
Authority Having Jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Ord. 1925. Passed 7-8-99.)
 
925.34 PROXIMITY TO OTHER UTILITIES.
   A minimum of eighteen (18) inches vertical separation and a minimum of ten
(10) feet horizontal separation shall be maintained between sanitary sewer
lines and water lines. Separation from any other utilities shall be subject to
the approval of the Authority having jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.35 MINIMUM SEWER MAIN SIZES.
   (a)   The minimum acceptable sewer main size shall be eight (8) inches.
However, the proposed sewer main shall be of adequate capacity to serve the
anticipated needs of the proposed project and, where applicable, the service
area of which it is a part.
 
   (b)   The proposed size of new sewer mains shall be reviewed by, and subject
to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.36 MINIMUM TAP AND SERVICE LATERAL SIZES.
   The minimum acceptable sizes for new sanitary taps and service laterals
shall be as follows:
   (a)   For one and two family dwellings. Each dwelling unit shall have a
minimum service lateral size of six (6) inches.
   (b)   For all other uses the proposed individual service and/or service
lateral size shall be adequate for the projected service needs, but not less
than six (6) inches, and shall be subject to the approval of the Municipal
Engineer.
   (c)   If any existing building or structure, having a sanitary sewer user
connection, is hereafter enlarged or demolished and replaced by a new building
or structure and the size of the existing tap and service lateral are
inadequate to serve the resulting building then a new tap and service lateral
shall be required.
   (d)   If, within any existing building or structure or part thereof, the
tenancy changes to a different user classification and the size of the existing
tap and service lateral are inadequate to serve the resulting building tenancy
then a new tap and service lateral shall be required.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2124. Passed 7-11-02.)
 
925.50 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
 
925.51 INSTALLATION REQUIRED.
   The improvements required herein are deemed the minimum necessary provisions
for the protection of the Municipality's sanitary sewerage system; and for
providing essential services for the protection of the public safety, health
and general welfare. The improvements required herein shall be provided,
installed and/or constructed by the applicant for sewer service, at his expense
and as herein required.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.52 DEDICATION TO PUBLIC USE.
   All sanitary sewer lines, excepting service laterals to a specific building
or fee simple lot, shall be dedicated to public use unless otherwise approved
by Council. Easements for dedicated improvements shall also be provided to the
Municipality in accordance with the requirements of Section
925.33 (Easements and Rights Of Way).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.53 RESPONSIBILITY FOR TAP WORK.
   (a)   All sewer tap-ins on existing sewer mains shall be made by authorized
Municipal employees only.
 
   (b)   During the construction of a new sanitary sewer main, the developer
may install such connections for service laterals and other new sewer mains as
are shown in the approved construction documents for the subject development
project. The tap-in of the new sewer main, or mains, to existing mains shall be
done by the Municipality in accordance with subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.54 EXTENSION OF EXISTING SEWERS.
   Where sanitary sewer mains are accessible, in the opinion of the
Municipality, within 1000 feet of a proposed subdivision or planned unit
development project said sewer mains shall be extended to the subject property,
and a public sanitary sewer system provided thereon, for the use of all lots
and/or building sites in the development project.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.55 REQUIRED CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   Connections to the Municipal sanitary sewer system shall be required
for any lot or land where water is to be consumed and/or used, or upon which
sanitary sewage or industrial waste will be generated, by any person,
corporation or other entity, when said lot or land fronts or abuts any street
in the Municipality where a sanitary sewer main exists; or abuts any easement
or right of way which would provide for the extension of sewer mains, or
service laterals, from another property in accordance with the requirements of
Section
925.54 (Extension of Existing Sewers).
 
   (b)   After the acceptance by Council of any newly constructed and dedicated
sanitary sewer, a period of one year will be allowed for making the proper
connection thereto in accordance with the requirements of subsection (a)
hereof. Such connection shall be permitted only after inspection and approval
of existing plumbing.
 
   (c)   If, upon any lot or parcel of land where a user connection to the
sanitary sewer system already exists, the building, structure or other facility
thereon is altered, enlarged, reconstructed, or is proposed for such change in
use that the existing tap and service lateral are inadequate to serve the
modified building or use, then a new tap and service lateral, conforming to
these regulations, shall be required.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.56 PROVIDE FOR FUTURE CONNECTIONS.
   When new sanitary sewer mains are to be constructed the following provisions
for future connections shall be made.
   (a)   When the required size of the service lateral to a lot or building
site can be predetermined, a stubbed service lateral, conforming to Municipal
specifications, shall be installed for the future use of said lot and/or
building site. The connection shall be made and the service lateral extended to
the street right of way line. The terminus of the lateral shall be capped and
its location marked with a wood pole or other device approved by the Authority
having jurisdiction. When sewer lines are not installed within a public right
of way the required lateral shall be installed to a point approved by the
Authority having jurisdiction. When the service lateral size cannot be
predetermined the future applicant for sanitary sewer service shall be required
to conform to Section
925.57 (Street Opening and Boring).
   (b)   When the subject property abuts undeveloped lands, the developer shall
extended sewer mains, and easements for same, to the property line in a manner,
and in such locations, as the Approving Authority for the subject project may
reasonably require in accordance with accepted engineering standards and
practices so as to provide for the continuation of service to said undeveloped
lands in the future. When, in accordance with the Land Planning and Development
Regulations, the present construction of said sewer lines is not warranted, the
developer shall be required to provide the necessary sewer line easements to
connect with said abutting lands.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.57 STREET OPENING AND BORING.
   (a)   Wherever street crossings are necessary and the depth of existing
services is sufficient, connection to existing sewer mains shall be made by
boring the service lateral under the street pavement. The cutting, or opening
of street pavements shall be avoided whenever other reasonable alternatives are
available in the opinion of the Authority having jurisdiction.
 
   (b)   Any street opening and/or boring, and the restoration thereof, shall
be in accordance with the requirements for same set forth in Chapter
901  (Street Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.58 PROPER CONNECTION REQUIRED.
   Any connection to the Municipal sewerage system shall be in strict
conformance with this regulation and other applicable regulations and standards
of the Municipality.
   (a)   BUILDING CODE COMPLIANCE. All building sanitary plumbing and plumbing
fixtures shall conform with all applicable building and plumbing code
requirements. No person owning or using a water closet, bath, sink or other
sanitary fixture shall operate the same in any manner unless the same is
properly connected to a Municipal sanitary sewer.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1892. Passed 3-11-99.)
 
925.59 SAMPLING MANHOLE REQUIRED.
   The owner of any non-residential property served by a sanitary sewer shall
install a suitable control manhole in the sanitary sewer lateral, at a location
approved by the Authority having jurisdiction, to facilitate observation,
sampling and measurement of wastes. Such a manhole shall be accessible and
safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with Municipal
specifications for sanitary sewer manholes. The manhole shall be installed by
the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and
accessible at all times.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.70 SEWER SYSTEM OPERATION.
 
925.71 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   (a)   The Authority having jurisdiction, or his duly authorized agent, shall
have access at all reasonable hours, between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to any
premises connected to a Municipal sanitary sewer, to make necessary
examinations, readings and repairs.
 
   (b)   Authorized Municipal employees bearing proper credentials and
identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose
of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing of the wastewater
in accordance with the provisions of this section. They shall have no authority
to inquire into any process beyond that point having a direct bearing on the
nature and source of wastewaters and their volumes and points of entry into the
Municipal wastewater collection system. they shall observe all safety
regulations which are applicable to the premises.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.72 SYSTEM DAMAGE AND TAMPERING.
   No person shall injure, break or remove any portion of any pipe, manhole,
plug, cover or other part of the Municipal sewerage system except as authorized
for the purpose of making repairs or connection to the system in accordance
with this regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.73 SERVICE OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   Sewer connections and/or tap-ins, and trunk lines, or any sanitary sewer
services shall not be provided, extended or furnished to any person,
corporation or any other entity, if the location of the service is beyond the
municipal corporation limits. Present users of the municipal water system,
located outside of the municipal corporation limit, are exempt from this
section.
(Ord. 1185. Passed 10-13-88.)
 
925.74 PROHIBITED CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   No person shall connect the downspouts of any building or the waste
drain of any hydrant or water plug, either directly or indirectly with any
sanitary sewer, or permit any storm water to be discharged in any manner into
such sewer.
(Ord. 30. Passed 3-2-16.)
 
   (b)   No person shall connect any open gutter, cesspool or privy vault with
any Municipal sewer or with any private sewer which is connected to such
Municipal sewer.
(Ord. 30. Passed 3-2-16.)
 
   (c)   No person shall connection to a sanitary sewer, whether by direct or
indirect tap, any roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains
or other sources of surface runoff or ground water.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.75 ABANDONMENT OF SERVICE.
   At any time a sanitary sewer user connection is to be abandon, then the
connection shall be excavated at the point of tap-in; the service lateral to be
abandon shall be disconnected in an approved manner; and the tap connection
shall be tightly and permanently capped. If the sewer main is deteriorated at
the point of connection with the service lateral, then the sewer main pipe
shall be replace with a new section of sewer pipe. Inspection of all work shall
be required under the provisions of Section
925.93 (Construction Inspection and Testing) prior to backfilling the
excavation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.76 PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
   No user shall discharge, or otherwise introduce, into the Municipal sewerage
system any materials that cause interference with the Municipal wastewater
treatment plant, or which will pass through said plant in such a manner as to
cause, or increase, a violation of the Municipality's NPDES permit
requirements. Such deleterious materials or substances shall include, but are
not limited to, those set forth hereinafter. The following list shall be
subject to revisions, as necessary, to meet current water quality standards
imposed by State or Federal agencies.
   (a)   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature greater than 150 degree
Fahrenheit.
   (b)   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0, or
having any other corrosive property which may cause damage or hazard to
structures, equipment or other appurtenances of the sewer system or to
personnel.
   (c)   Any water or wastes containing emulsified oils and greases which, on
laboratory analysis, is found to contain an average of fifty (50) milligrams/
liter, or greater, of said oils and greases.
   (d)   Flammable and explosive substances, such as gasoline, kerosene,
benzene, naphtha or other substances capable of causing flammable or explosive
conditions.
   (e)   Any materials or substances which singly, or by interaction with other
wastes, would create a public nuisance or may constitute a hazard to life or
welfare of personnel engaged in inspection, maintenance and operation of the
sewerage system.
   (f)   Any solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction of the
flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage
system. Said substances shall include, but are not limited to: construction
materials, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastic, wood, fur and/or wax; and garbage which has not been
properly shredded into particles no greater than one-half (½) inch in any
dimension.
   (g)   Any liquids or waste containing toxic or poisonous substances in
sufficient quantities, or rate of flow, as to injure or interfere with the
sewage treatment process; to constitute a hazard to human beings or animals; or
to create any hazard in the receiving waters.
   (h)   Any materials or substances which are in any way deleterious to any
part of the sewerage system.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.77 INDUSTRIAL WASTE DISCHARGES.
   The discharge of industrial wastes shall be governed by such Industrial
Waste Discharge Regulation as may be adopted by Council (see Chapter 926).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.78 UNACCEPTABLE WASTEWATER.
   The Municipality shall make and enforce rules and regulations establishing
the types and characteristics of sewage, industrial wastes and other matter
which shall not be discharged into the sanitary sewerage system, the types and
characteristics of sewage and industrial wastes admissible to the system only
after pretreatment, requisites for pretreatment and otherwise governing the
discharge of sewage, industrial wastes and other matter into the system in the
interest of safety and the efficient operation of the wastewater treatment
plant.
   (a)   In cases where the character of sewage or industrial waste from any
manufacturing or industrial plant, building or premises is such that it will
damage the sewerage system or cannot be treated satisfactorily at the
wastewater treatment plant, the Municipality shall compel such users to dispose
of such waste and prevent it from entering the sewerage system.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
   (b)   In cases where the character of the sewage or industrial waste from
any manufacturing or industrial plant, building or premises is such that it
imposes an unreasonable burden upon the sewage collection, pumping or treatment
works greater than that imposed by the average sewage entering the sewerage
system, the Municipality may, if it deems advisable, compel such manufacturing
or industrial plant, building or premises to pretreat such sewage in such
manner as it specifies before discharging such sewage into the sewerage system.
Industrial waste shall be pretreated to the strength of normal waste (see
definition for "normal sewage" Section
920.001 ; Public Utilities Code).
      (Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
   (c)   The discharge of unacceptable industrial wastewater into the sewerage
system, whether directly or indirectly, is prohibited. Wastewater shall be
deemed unacceptable when the concentration of harmful or toxic substances in
the wastewater exceeds certain prescribed tolerable limits.
   (d)   Toxic or harmful substances include, but are not necessarily limited
to the following:
 
TOXIC OR HARMFUL SUBSTANCES TOLERABLE LIMITS (milligrams/liter)
Arsenic                     0.05
Barium                      1.0
Boron                       5.0
Cadmium                     0.05
Chromium +3                 0.5
Chromium +6                 0.5
Cobalt                      1.0
Copper                   0.5
Cyanide (HCN)               0.1
Fluoride                    5.0
Iron                        5.0
Lead                        0.5
Mercury                     0.002
Molybdenum                  5.0
Nickel                      2.0
Phenols                     5.0
Selenium                    0.01
Silver                      0.03
Sulfides                    50.0
Total dissolved solids      1500.0
Tungsten                    5.0
Zinc                        2.0
                            1000 micro-microcuries/ liter Gross Beta activity
Radioactive substances      (in the known absence of strontium and Alpha
                            emitters).
 
   Any toxic substance as defined in the Federal Register, Volume 38, published
September 7, 1973, shall not be discharged to the sanitary sewer system in
concentrations which exceed 0.1 of the ninety-six (96) hour median tolerance
limit.
   The preceding list of toxic or harmful substances is subject to revisions as
required to meet current water quality standards and/or effluent standards
imposed by State or Federal agencies.
(Ord 749. Passed 4-3-80.)
 
925.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY.
 
925.91 PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE.
   Any person, corporation or other entity proposing work within the scope of
this regulation shall be required to post such performance guarantees as are
required by the provisions of Section
920.91 of the Public Utilities Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.92 CONFORM TO APPROVED PLAN.
   Any work done within the scope of these regulations shall be in strict
conformance with the plans and specifications for same as approved by the
Municipality. Any deviation therefrom shall require the specific written
approval of the Approving Authority for the subject project.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.93 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   (a)   All work within the scope of these regulations shall be subject to
full time inspection and supervision by the Municipality, and subject to
materials testing, for determination, and assurance, of conformance with the
approved plans, specifications, and applicable Municipal requirements in
accordance with the requirements of Section
920.93 of the Public Utilities Code.
 
   (b)   The person obtaining a sanitary sewer work permit shall notify the
Authority having jurisdiction, or his designate, at least three (3) days before
the work is to commence to schedule the required inspections. In so reporting,
exact location of the work to be inspected shall be identified. No tap or
connection shall be made except in the presence of a Municipal sewer inspector.
The sewer line, or lateral, leading to such tap or connection shall not be
filled, but must be left opened, and shall not be used until any required tests
have been completed and written approval of the work has been issued by the
inspector.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.94 MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE.
   The developer shall guarantee the materials and workmanship of all
improvements required by this regulation to be dedicated to public use. Said
maintenance bond shall be in accordance with the terms and conditions set forth
in Section
1151.94 (Maintenance Guarantee) of the Land Planning and Development
Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
925.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this regulation or fails to comply with
any order issued pursuant to these regulations shall be charged with, and
subject to the penalties for, the following:
      First offense: Minor misdemeanor.
      Second offense: Fourth degree misdemeanor.
      All offenses thereafter: First degree misdemeanor.
   Each day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)

927.00 GENERAL.
 
927.01 SCOPE OF REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The construction, reconstruction, alteration, extension, or excavation
of any part of the municipal water system, or any connection thereto, shall be
in accordance with these regulations.
 
   (b)   The terms and conditions under which the Municipality will provide
water service shall be as set forth in this regulation and Chapter
921  (Water Service Charges).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.02 PRIVATE WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall use any private water supply,
including but not limited to a well, cistern or spring, to supply water for
human consumption and human use inside a dwelling, building or structure. Water
from a private water supply shall be used only for a geothermal heating system,
outside a building, dwelling or structure or such other use approved by the
authority having jurisdiction which shall not drain into the sanitary sewer
system.
 
   (b)   Any person, firm or corporation using a private water supply upon the
passage of this section may continue to use said private water supply for human
consumption and human use within a dwelling, building or structure until such
time as a connection to the municipal water system shall be required pursuant
to §
927.55  of the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 471. Passed 6-13-68; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.03 WATER STORAGE; MUNICIPAL LIABILITY.
   Any person using water to feed water cooled equipment or steam boilers by
direct pressure from the mains, is hereby requested to provide such additional
storage as will enable him to tide over such times as the water supply may be
shut off in an emergency. The Municipality will not be liable for any damage
resulting from the necessary or accidental shutting off of the water supply.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
927.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   The Public Service Director shall be responsible for the administration and
enforcement of this regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.12 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   A water service work permit shall be required for all work within the
scope of this regulation. The permit requirements shall be as set forth herein
and in Section
920.12 of the Public Utilities Code.
 
   (b)   No permits for building construction shall be issued for any lot or
lands, for which Municipal water service is required, until a water service
work permit has been issued by the Municipality.
 
   (c)   Every person, firm or corporation desiring water service shall first
make written application to the Authority having jurisdiction, or his
designate, on a blank furnished for that purpose. Such application shall be
signed by the owners of such property or their duly authorized agent.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.13 PROJECT SUBMITTAL PROCEDURE; RECORD DRAWINGS.
   (a)   The submittal of proposed water line work or improvements shall be in
accordance with the requirements of Section
920.13 of the Public Utilities Code.
      (1)   When proposed water lines are not a part of another project, the
submittal shall be in accordance with the requirements for Lands For Public Use
when the work will be dedicated to public use; or the requirements for single
building site development when the work is for a private water line.
      (2)   The Municipal Engineer's review and approval shall include, but is
not limited to, system design, depth of service, location, capacity and
specifications. Copies of all design calculations shall be submitted for review
by, and shall be subject to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer.
 
   (b)   Record drawings for water service improvements shall be required. The
developer shall conform to the requirements set forth in Section
920.13 of the Public Utilities Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.14 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   These rules and regulations may be amended or altered at any time. The
Manager may make any such additional rules and regulations in respect thereto
as may be necessary for the protection and management of the Municipal water
system.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.30 PLANNING AND DESIGN.
 
927.31 DESIGN STANDARDS.
   Proposed water lines shall be planned, designed and constructed in
accordance with these regulations and as required by the Land Planning and
Development Regulations, Comprehensive Plan, Municipal Water Distribution Plan,
American Water Works Association Standards, accepted engineering practices and
standards, Municipal Standard Specifications For Water Lines and such other
adopted regulations and master plans of the Municipality as may be applicable.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.32 MUNICIPAL SPECIFICATIONS.
   All water service lines (whether public or private) shall be constructed in
accordance with the Municipal Standard Specification for Water Service Lines.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.33 EASEMENTS AND RIGHTS OF WAY.
   When water mains proposed to be dedicated to public use are not located
within a dedicated street right of way, the developer shall grant a utility
easement or right of way to the Municipality, for the purpose of operating,
maintaining, enlarging, repairing, replacing, removing, relocating or adding
municipal utilities. Said easement or right of way width shall be equal to
twice the depth of the water main plus ten (10) feet or thirty (30) feet in
width, whichever is greater, or as otherwise required by the Approving
Authority. The water main shall be located inside the easement at a distance
equal to one-half (½) the depth of the water main or at such other depth
required by the Authority Having Jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1925. Passed 7-8-99.)
 
927.34 PROXIMITY TO OTHER UTILITIES.
   A minimum of eighteen (18) inches vertical separation and a minimum of ten
(10) feet horizontal separation shall be maintained between water lines and
sanitary sewer lines. The separation of water lines from other utilities shall
be subject to the approval of the Authority having jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.35 MINIMUM SIZE OF WATER MAINS.
   (a)   The minimum acceptable water main sizes shall be as follows:
      (1)   One and two family dwelling areas: eight (8) inches.
      (2)   All other areas: twelve (12) inches.
      (3)   Water trunk mains: sixteen (16) inches.
 
   (b)   All water mains and service laterals that supply fire hydrants shall
be of sufficient size to provide the required fire flow for the area, or
property, in which they are located. However, no such water main or service
lateral shall be less than eight (8) inches. Determination of the required fire
flow shall be in accordance with the requirements and provisions of the Fire
Prevention Code.
 
   (c)   The proposed size of new water mains shall be reviewed by, and subject
to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer and the Authority having
jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.36 MINIMUM SIZE OF TAPS AND SERVICE LATERALS.
   The minimum acceptable sizes for water service shall be as follows:
   (a)   Each residential dwelling unit shall have a minimum service size of
three-fourths (¾) inch; excepting that transient residence facilities shall be
required to conform to all other requirements of this section.
(Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
   (b)   For single family residential units with fixed fire suppression
systems that are permitted to be supplied from the building's domestic water
supply, the service lateral shall be of sufficient size to meet the domestic
water demand plus the fire suppression demand. The proposed lateral size shall
be approved by the Municipal Engineer and the Director of Public Service.
      (Ord. 2809. Passed 1-9-14.)
   (c)   Service laterals for automatic fire protection sprinkler systems shall
be sized in accordance with the requirements of the Fire Prevention Code.
   (d)   For all other uses the proposed individual service and/or service
lateral size shall be subject to the approval of the Municipal Engineer and the
Authority having jurisdiction.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.37 APPROVED PIPE SIZES.
   The range of pipe sizes which may be used for water service lines shall be
limited to the following: ¾"; 1"; 1½"; 2"; 3"; 4"; 6"; 8"; 12"; 16".
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.38 CURB SHUTOFF AND METER REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   One and two family dwellings. A separate curb shutoff and meter shall
be required for each dwelling unit.
 
   (b)   Multifamily and Commercial Buildings. Service may be configured by any
of the following methods:
      (1)   One curb shutoff and meter for the entire building.
      (2)   One curb shutoff and a manifold with one meter for each tenant unit
and one meter for general building water uses.
      (3)   One curb shutoff and meter for each tenant unit.
 
   (c)   Industrial and Institutional buildings. Each service lateral for
domestic and/or process water purposes shall have a separate curb shutoff and
meter.
 
   (d)   Service laterals which serve only automatic fire protection sprinkler
systems shall have a curb shutoff but shall not have a water meter.
 
   (e)   In addition to the requirements of divisions (a) through (d), each
dwelling, building or structure may have one secondary water line. The
secondary water line shall be installed inside the structure and connected to
the primary water line between its point of entry to the structure and the
primary water line water meter.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.39 SECONDARY WATER LINE FOR OUTSIDE USE.
   (a)   One secondary water line for outside water usage is permitted for each
building, dwelling or structure connected by a service lateral to a water main.
The secondary water line shall be connected to the primary water line within
the dwelling, building or structure at a location between the point of entry to
the structure and the primary water line water meter. A secondary water line
water meter shall be attached to the secondary water line. The secondary water
line shall only be used to provide water outside of the dwelling, building or
structure and shall not be discharged into the sanitary sewer system. The
secondary water line shall be attached to an outside faucet or faucets or other
outside water distribution system, such as a lawn or landscape sprinkling
system, intended solely for outside use.
 
   (b)   The owner or user of the dwelling, building or structure, shall be
responsible for obtaining all necessary permits, if any, required by §
920.12 ; payment of all permit fees required by §
920.18 ; the cost of construction, inspection and testing required by §
920.93 ; application deposit required by §
921.161 ; cost for municipal construction, inspection and testing as set forth
in §
921.165 ; the cost for the secondary water line water meter and remote reading
device required therefore by §
921.166 ; and such other requirements, costs, fees and expenses imposed by
Chapters
920 ,
921  and
927  of the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.50 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
 
927.51 INSTALLATION REQUIRED.
   The improvements required herein are deemed the minimum necessary provisions
for the protection of the Municipality's water supply; and for providing
essential services for the protection of the public safety, health and general
welfare. The improvements required herein shall be provided, installed and/or
constructed by the applicant for water service, at his expense and as herein
required.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.52 DEDICATION TO PUBLIC USE.
   All water lines, excepting service laterals to a specific building or fee
simple lot, shall be dedicated to public use. Easements for dedicated
improvements shall also be provided to the Municipality in accordance with the
requirements of Section
927.33 (Easements and Rights of way).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.53 RESPONSIBILITY FOR TAP WORK.
   (a)   Taps for three-fourths (¾) inch to two (2) inch services on Municipal
water mains, or parts thereof, designated by the Authority having jurisdiction
as requiring special care and/or attention, due to age or type of material of
said water main or for other good cause, shall be performed only by the
Municipal Water Department. The Municipality, after payment of the fees set
forth in Chapter
921  (Water Charges), shall make the connection from the main to the curb
shutoff. The applicant shall be responsible for all work and costs for
extending laterals from the curb shut off to the building or point of use.
 
   (b)   In all other instances, the applicant shall be responsible for all
work and costs relative to the tapping, connecting and extending of service
laterals and/or water mains.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.54 EXTENSION OF EXISTING MAINS.
   Where public water mains are accessible, in the opinion of the Municipality,
within 1000 feet of a development project said water mains shall be extended to
the subject property, and a public water system provided thereon, for the fire
protection and domestic water uses of all lots and/or building sites in said
development project.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.55 REQUIRED CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   Connections to the Municipal water system shall be required for any
lot or land where water is to be consumed and/or used, by any person, when said
lot or land fronts or abuts any street in the Municipality where a public water
main exists; or abuts any easement or right of way which would provide for the
extension of water mains, or service laterals, from another property.
 
   (b)   When a subject development property abuts an easement, or easements,
which would provide for the extension of water mains from existing water mains
on adjacent property, through the subject property, to another point of
connection with existing public water mains, the developer of the subject
property shall be required to install such water main, or mains, and connect
same so as to provide for gridding the Municipal water system and thereby
improve the reliability and service capacity of the system.
 
   (c)   Buildings equipped with an automatic sprinkler system shall have a
separate tap and service lateral to serve said system. Automatic fire
protection sprinkler systems, and other fixed fire suppression systems using
water as the extinguishing agent, shall be connected to the Municipal water
system in accordance with these regulations and the Fire Prevention Code.
Approved backflow prevention devices shall be required. Fixed fire suppression
systems which are permitted by the Fire Prevention Code and/or Building Code to
be serviced from a domestic water supply are exempt from the separate lateral
requirement.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.56 PROVIDE FOR FUTURE CONNECTION.
   When new water mains are to be constructed the following provisions for
future connections shall be made.
   (a)   When the required size of the service lateral to a lot or building
site can be predetermined, a water service connection and stubbed service
lateral and curb box, conforming to Municipal specifications, shall be
installed for the future use of said lot and/or building site. The connection
shall be made and the service lateral extended to the street right of way line.
The terminus of the lateral shall be capped and its location marked with a wood
pole or other device approved by the Authority having jurisdiction. When water
lines are not installed within a public right of way the required lateral shall
be installed to a point approved by the Authority having jurisdiction. When the
service lateral size cannot be predetermined the future applicant for water
service shall be required to conform to Section
927.57  (Street Opening and Boring).
   (b)   When the subject property abuts undeveloped lands, the developer shall
extended water mains, and easements for same, to the property line in a manner,
and in such locations, as the Approving Authority for the subject project may
reasonably require in accordance with accepted engineering standards and
practices so as to provide for the continuation of service to said undeveloped
lands in the future. When, in accordance with the Land Planning and Development
Regulations, the present construction of said water lines is not warranted, the
developer shall be required to provide the necessary water line easements to
connect with the adjacent land.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.57 STREET OPENING AND BORING.
   (a)   Wherever street crossings are necessary and the depth of existing
services is sufficient, connection to existing water mains shall be made by
boring, or pushing, the service lateral under the street pavement. The Cutting,
or opening of street pavements shall be avoided whenever other reasonable
alternatives are available in the opinion of the Authority having jurisdiction.
 
   (b)   Any street opening and/or boring, and the restoration thereof, shall
be in accordance with the requirements for same set forth in Chapter
901  (Street Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.58 PROPER CONNECTION REQUIRED.
   Any connection to the Municipal water system shall be in strict conformance
with this and other applicable regulations and standards of the Municipality.
   (a)   BUILDING CODE COMPLIANCE. All building water supply plumbing shall be
in conformance with all applicable building and plumbing code requirements.
   (b)   ANTI-SIPHON PROTECTION. Approved anti-siphon and backflow prevention
devices shall be provided and installed, by the applicant, as required by these
and other applicable regulations to protect the Municipal water supply from
contamination.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.59 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   Fire hydrants shall be provided and installed by the developer in accordance
with the following requirements.
   (a)   Hydrants shall conform to, and shall be installed in accordance with,
Municipal specifications.
   (b)   Fire hydrants shall be installed along public and private streets at
the following maximum intervals, unless otherwise approved by the Authority
having jurisdiction and the Fire Prevention officer.
      (1)   One and two family dwelling areas: 300 feet.
      (2)   All other areas: 250 feet.
   (c)   Upon private property, yard hydrants shall be installed in such
locations as may be required by the Fire Prevention Officer under the
provisions of the Fire Prevention Code and Building Code.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.60 FIRE SUPPRESSION WATER FLOW.
   (a)   The developer of a proposed subdivision or PUD project shall design
and construct water distribution systems to meet the minimum fire suppression
water flow requirements set forth in the current edition of the Insurance
Service Office, Fire Suppression Rating Schedule.
 
   (b)   Water distribution systems proposed for dedication to public use shall
not be accepted by the Municipality unless said systems meet the minimum fire
suppression water flow required herein. The Municipality shall verify
compliance by testing the flow of the systems.
(Ord. 1922. Passed 7-8-99.)
 
927.70 WATER SYSTEM OPERATION.
 
927.71 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Municipality shall be permitted access to any premises supplied with
water during regular business hours to make inspections, readings, repairs or
replacement of water meters, water usage measuring devices or other water
service equipment.
(Ord. 2809. Passed 1-9-14.)
 
927.72 SYSTEM DAMAGE AND TAMPERING.
   (a)   No person shall injure, break or remove any portion of any curbbox,
pipe, hydrant, plug or any other part of the Municipal water system except as
authorized for the purpose of making repairs or connection in accordance with
these regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
   (b)   No person unless authorized by the Water Department, shall remove the
cover of any curb box, or place dirt, stone or other obstruction in such boxes,
or commit any act intending to obstruct the use of same.
(Ord. 247. Passed 5-6-54.)
 
   (c)   No plumber or other person shall turn the water on or off at the curb
box, or allow any other person to do so, except with the permission of the
Authority having jurisdiction.
 
   (d)   No person shall turn the water on or off at any fire hydrant, except
with the permission of the Fire Chief or the Authority having jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.73 SERVICE OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   Water connections and/or tap-ins, and/or water lines shall not be provided
or extended or furnished to any person, corporation or any entity, if the
location or service is beyond the municipal corporation limits. Present users
of the municipal water system, located outside of the municipal corporation
limit, are hereby exempt from this section.
(Ord. 1184. Passed 1-13-88.)
 
927.74 PROHIBITED CONNECTIONS.
   Cross connection between the Municipal' water system and any other utility
or any private water system, spring, well or cistern is prohibited. Connection
of the Municipal water system to any other public water system shall require
the express written approval of the Council of the City of Chardon.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.75 ABANDONMENT OF SERVICE; VOLUNTARY TEMPORARY DISCONNECTION.
   (a)   At any time a water service user connection is to be abandon, the
connection shall be excavated at the point of tap-in; the service lateral shall
be disconnected at the tap valve or corporation stop in a manner approved by
the Municipal inspector; and the tap connection shall be tightly and
permanently capped. If the water main is deteriorate at the point of connection
with the service lateral, then the water main pipe shall be replace with a new
section of main pipe. Inspection of any work shall be required under the
provisions of Section
927.93 (Construction Inspection and Testing) prior to backfilling the
excavation.
 
   (b)   Voluntary temporary disconnection. Any water service user may request
the municipality to temporarily shut off water service. All temporary shutoff
shall be at the curb box, which shall shut off all water to the structure, both
the primary and secondary water lines. The secondary water line shall not be
separately shut off independently from the primary water line. Resumption of
water service requires payment of the turn-on charge set forth in §
921.168 .
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.76 LIMITATIONS ON WATER USAGE.
   (a)   At any time when a dangerous shortage of water supply in the
Municipality necessitates limiting the use of water in the interest of its
conservation, the Manager may proclaim a condition of emergency within the
Municipality and prescribe permissive uses of the public water supply.
 
   (b)   Any proclamation by the Manager or his designee shall set forth any
use of water forbidden in the interest of conservation and shall prescribe the
effective date. Notice of such proclamation shall be posted conspicuously
within the Municipality and advertised at least once in a newspaper of general
circulation.
 
   (c)   No person shall violate the terms of such proclamation issued pursuant
to this section.
(Ord. 229. Passed 9-3-53.)
 
927.77 WATER SHUT OFF.
   The Municipality, by its Manager shall have and hereby reserves the right at
all times to shut the water off at the mains for making repairs, extensions or
any other purposes. The Municipality will endeavor to give notice of such
action.
(Ord. 247. Passed 5-6-54.)
 
927.78 WATER METER INSTALLATION.
   (a)   Water meters and remote meter reading devices shall be provided by the
Municipality at the cost of the owner or user as set forth in Chapter
921  (Water Service Charges). Every water meter and remote meter reading device
shall be installed in accordance with this chapter and municipal regulations
and specifications.
 
   (b)   Editor’s Note: Former subsection (b) hereof was repealed by Ordinance
2809.
 
   (c)   Water meters shall be installed by the Municipality unless otherwise
permitted by the Authority having jurisdiction. Said meters shall generally be
located inside a building or structure; at the lowest possible floor level;
protected from freezing; and in a readily accessible position for ease of
reading and service. Whenever possible water meters shall be adjacent to an
exterior wall. The location of a water meter shall be subject to the approval
of the Authority having jurisdiction, or designee. Water meters shall be
mounted not less than six (6) inches nor more than fifty-six (56) inches above
the finished floor; shall be horizontally level and plumb; shall be installed
in the service line before any branch, tee, wye or other type of connection
(except as provided herein for fixed fire suppression systems serviced from the
domestic water supply and secondary water line); and shall have shutoff valves
immediately before and after the meter and prior to any branch, tee, wye or
other type of connection.
 
   (d)   One secondary water line water meter shall be permitted for each
building, dwelling or structure. Installation of the secondary water meter
shall comply with all other requirements of this section.
 
   (e)   Manifold meters shall be installed within six (6) feet of the water
line entry point into the building. Said meters shall be within twelve (12)
inches of each other.
 
   (f)   Any violation of this section shall be corrected at the property
owner’s expense. The Municipality shall cause the correction of such violation.
When the corrective work is done by the Municipality a charge therefore shall
be made in accordance with the provisions of Chapter
921  (Water Service Charges); such charge shall be payable as any other water
charge.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.79 METER CARE AND REPAIR.
   All users of the water system shall protect the water meters from frost and
all water users are cautioned against allowing their meters to freeze. Any
meter found damaged by frost shall be repaired and the cost thereof will be
charged to the property on which the meter was used. The same applies to
allowing meters to be injured by hot water.
(Ord. 247. Passed 5-6-54.)
 
927.80 BYPASSING METER PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person, corporation or firm shall bypass, or permit the bypass of,
any water meter which is installed to measure the water consumed by such person
or on a property which may be owned by such person.
 
   (b)   No person, corporation or firm shall allow water used from the
secondary water line to drain into the sanitary sewer system.
(Ord. 883. Passed 4-7-83; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
927.81 WATER METER TESTING.
   Should a person require of the Municipality that their water meter be tested
for accuracy of measurement of water, failure, or other items relating thereto,
the City shall test such meter. If such meter is within the applicable
operating parameters set forth by the American Water Works Association
Standards (a copy of such standards being on file with the Clerk of Council, or
Public Service Director, and the Geauga County Law Library) the meter so tested
shall be returned to the property and the property owner shall pay both a
service charge for the meter test and an installation charge for reinstallation
of the meter (see Chapter
921 (Water Service Charges) Section
921.17 (Charge For Meter Testing)). Should the water meter so tested fail to
meet the standards as set forth herein, the meter shall be replaced at no
charge to the property owner.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.82 CONSTRUCTION WATER SERVICE.
   Contractors requiring a temporary service connection for the use of water
during construction shall make application for same to the Authority having
jurisdiction, or his designate. The water supply point shall be subject to the
approval of the Authority having jurisdiction; and a water meter shall be
installed thereon. Deposits and charges for the temporary water meter, its
hookup and any water used shall be paid as required by Chapter
921  (Water Service Charges).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.83 RESALE OR DISTRIBUTION OF MUNICIPAL WATER.
   (a)    No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from
the city water supply to any premises other than that for which application has
been made and the water installed, except in emergency situations where
distribution of such water is necessary to ensure the health, safety, and
welfare of the City, or where the City has expressly authorized such resale or
distribution.
   (b)    Whoever violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first
degree."
(Ord. 3121. Passed 7-9-20.)
 
927.90 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY.
 
927.91 PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE.
   Any person, corporation or other entity proposing work within the scope of
this regulation shall be required to post such performance guarantees as are
required by the provisions of Section
920.91 of the Public Utilities Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.92 CONFORM TO APPROVED PLAN.
   Any work done within the scope of these regulations shall be in strict
conformance with the plans and specifications for same as approved by the
Municipality. Any deviation therefrom shall require the specific written
approval of the Approving Authority for the subject project.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.93 CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION AND TESTING.
   (a)   All work within the scope of these regulations shall be subject to
full time inspection and supervision by the Municipality, and subject to
materials testing, for determination, and assurance, of conformance with the
approved plans, specifications, and applicable Municipal requirements in
accordance with the requirements set forth in Section
920.93 of the Public Utilities Code.
 
   (b)   Service laterals and water mains shall be hydrostatically tested in
accordance with the requirements and standards of the American Water Works
Association and/or the Fire Prevention Code as is appropriate to their service
and function.
 
   (c)   Hydrant installations shall be subject to testing and approval, by the
Municipality, for proper operation and required fire flow capacity prior to
final construction inspection approval.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.94 MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE.
   The developer shall guarantee the materials and workmanship of all
improvements required by this regulation to be dedicated to public use. Said
maintenance bond shall be in accordance with the terms and conditions set forth
in Section
1151.94 (Maintenance Guarantee) of the Land Planning and Development
Regulations.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
927.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, or any order issued
pursuant thereto, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. In addition
to the penalties imposed herein, any person, firm or corporation which violates
§§
927.02 ,
927.39 ,
927.78 (d) or
927.80  shall be fined a minimum of $500 for the first violation, $750 for the
second violation and $1,000 for the third and any subsequent violation.
 
   (b)   Any violation hereunder shall constitute a separate offense on each
successive day continued.
 
   (c)   In addition to the penalties set forth herein, any person who
illegally bypasses a water meter, or illegally bypasses a primary water line
water meter to a secondary water line, shall be charged such amount as may be
determined by the Authority having jurisdiction for the use of such illegally
consumed water from the date the illegal consumption of water begins until the
date that the correction is made, inspected and approved.
 
   (d)   Any fine authorized hereunder imposed by a court of competent
jurisdiction and any charge imposed by the Authority having jurisdiction for
illegal consumption of water is made a lien upon the corresponding lot, parcel
of land, dwelling, building, structure or premises, which is served by a
connection to the water system of the Municipality. If the fine or charge is
delinquent for more than 30 days, the Finance Director may certify such amount
due to the county auditor, at which time the lien shall vest. The county
auditor shall place the same on the tax duplicate of Geauga County. In
addition, the Geauga County Auditor shall cause interest and penalties to be
imposed for non-payment of charges for illegal consumption of water as provided
by Chapter
920  and cause such amount to be collected as other municipal taxes are
collected. No interest or penalty shall be charged for unpaid court fines.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 2093. Passed 12-13-01.)
 
   (e)   The City Manager shall order the water be shut off at the main if the
owner or occupant of premises supplied by water refuses to permit access and
right of entry in violation of Section
927.71.
(Ord. 2809. Passed 1-9-14.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 928
Regulations for Acceptance of Septic Discharge
 
928.01   Authority of City Manager.
928.02   Registration and application fee.
928.03   Rates.
928.04   Other regulations and conditions.
 
928.01 AUTHORITY OF CITY MANAGER.
   The City Manager is authorized and directed to establish regulations and
impose terms and conditions upon any hauler discharging domestic residential
septage within the City, and to control the discharge of septage waste at the
waste water treatment plant.
(Ord. 2192. Passed 2-12-04; Am. Ord. 2391. Passed 2-8-07.)
 
928.02 REGISTRATION AND APPLICATION FEE.
   Every hauler shall provide a copy of the registration received from the
County Health Department and a non-refundable application fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per year.
(Ord. 2192. Passed 2-12-04; Am. Ord. 2391. Passed 2-8-07.)
 
928.03 RATES.
   The City shall charge forty dollars ($40.00) per 1,000 gallons of
residential domestic septage waste discharged at the waste water treatment
plant.
(Ord. 2192. Passed 2-12-04; Am. Ord. 2391. Passed 2-8-07.)
 
928.04 OTHER REGULATIONS AND CONDITIONS.
   The Manager shall implement such other regulations and conditions for
controlling septage discharge that are in the best interest of the City.
(Ord. 2192. Passed 2-12-04; Am. Ord. 2391. Passed 2-8-07.)

925.74
 
929.00 GENERAL.
 
929.01 SCOPE OF REGULATION.
   The construction, reconstruction, alteration, extension of, or connection to
the Municipal storm sewer system sewer shall be in accordance with the
requirements of this regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.02 OPEN DRAINAGE FACILITIES.
   Open drainage facilities including, but not limited to, drainage ditches,
storm water detention areas, open channel waterways and retention ponds shall
be in accordance with the requirements of Chapter
1153  (Grading and Surface Water Drainage Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.10 ADMINISTRATION.
 
929.11 AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION.
   The Public Service Director shall be responsible for the administration and
enforcement of this regulation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.12 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   A storm sewer work permit shall be required for all work within the
scope of this regulation. The permit requirements shall be as set forth herein
and in §
920.12  of the Public Utilities Code.
 
   (b)   Application for connection to the municipal storm sewer system shall
be made upon the forms provided. The Authority Having Jurisdiction may require
such additional information as is necessary to insure conformance with, or
provide for the enforcement of, all applicable municipal regulations and
requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.13 PROJECT SUBMITTAL PROCEDURE; RECORD DRAWINGS.
   (a)   The submittal of proposed storm sewer work or improvements shall be in
accordance with the requirements of §
920.13  of the Public Utilities Code.
      (1)   When proposed sewer lines are not part of another project, the
submittal shall be in accordance with the requirements for Lands For Public Use
when the work will be dedicated to public use; or the requirements for single
building site development when the work is for a private sewer.
      (2)   The Municipal engineer's review and approval shall include, but is
not necessarily limited to, system design, sewer grade, location, capacity and
specifications. Copies of all design calculations shall be submitted for review
by, and shall be subject to the approval of, the Municipal Engineer.
   (b)   Record drawings for storm sewer improvements shall be required. The
developer shall conform to the requirements set forth in §
920.13  of the Public Utilities Code.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.14 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The City Manager shall establish rules and regulations as he deems
necessary for the safe, economical and efficient management and protection of
the municipal storm sewer system.
 
   (b)   Such rules and regulations shall be based upon accepted engineering
standards and practices where applicable. The rules and regulations shall have
the same force and effect as ordinances when not repugnant thereto or to state
law.
 
   (c)   The manager may amend, alter, or add to the rules and regulations as
he may from time to time deem necessary.
   (d)   The aforesaid rules and regulations shall be enforced by the City
Manager or his designated representative.
(Ord. 1210. Passed 03-09-89.)
 
929.30 PLANNING AND DESIGN.
 
929.31 DESIGN STANDARDS.
   Proposed storm sewer systems shall be planned, designed and constructed in
accordance with this regulation and as required by the Land Development
Regulations, Comprehensive Plan, Municipal Storm Water Drainage Plan, Municipal
Standard Specifications for Storm Sewers, Geauga Soil Sediment Pollution
Control Regulations, Ohio Department of Transportation Location and Design
Manual Vol. Two (Drainage Design) (§§ 1101 and 1103 through 1110), accepted
engineering practices and standards and such other regulations and master plans
of the Municipality as may be applicable. The referenced design standards shall
include such future amendments thereto as may hereafter be adopted by the
promulgating agency.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1506. Passed 2-10-94.)
 
929.32 MUNICIPAL SPECIFICATIONS.
   All storm sewer systems to be dedicated to public use shall be constructed
in accordance with the Municipal Specifications For Storm Sewers. All private
storm sewers shall be constructed in accordance with said specification unless
otherwise approved, or required, by Council.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.33 EASEMENTS AND RIGHTS OF WAY.
   When storm sewers which are to be dedicated to public use are not located
within a dedicated street right of way then a dedicated easement, or right of
way shall be provided by the developer for the purpose of operating and
maintaining the sewer lines. The easement or right of way shall be a minimum of
twenty feet in width unless a greater width is required by the Approving
Authority. The storm sewer center line shall be located five feet inside the
edge of the easement.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.34 PROXIMITY TO OTHER UTILITIES.
   A minimum of 18 inches vertical separation and a minimum of ten (10) feet
horizontal separation shall be maintained between storm sewers and any other
utilities, unless otherwise approved by the authority having jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.50 REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS.
 
929.51 INSTALLATION REQUIRED.
   The improvements required herein are deemed the minimum necessary provisions
for the protection of the Municipal storm sewer system; and for providing
essential services for the protection of the public safety, health and general
welfare. The improvements required herein shall be provided, installed and/or
constructed by the applicant for sewer service, at his expense and as herein
required.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.52 DEDICATION TO PUBLIC USE.
   (a)   Storm sewers required, or proposed, to be located within any public
right of way, or easement, shall be dedicated to public use.
 
   (b)   Storm sewers required, or proposed, to be located upon other than fee
simple lots shall be dedicated to public use unless otherwise approved by
Council.
 
   (c)   Storm sewers required, or proposed, to be located upon fee simple
lots, or parcels, shall be dedicated to public use when such is deemed
necessary by the Municipal Approving Authority for the public health, safety,
or general welfare.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.53 RESPONSIBILITY FOR TAP WORK.
   (a)   All storm sewer tap-ins on existing sewer mains shall be made by
authorized Municipal employees only.
 
   (b)   During the construction of a new storm sewer main, the developer may
install such connections for service laterals and other new sewer mains as are
shown in the approved construction documents for the subject development
project. The tap-in of the new sewer main, or mains, to existing mains shall be
done by the Municipality in accordance with subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.54 EXTENSION OF EXISTING MAINS.
   Where storm sewer mains are accessible, in the opinion of the Municipality,
within 1000 feet of a proposed subdivision or planned unit development project
said sewer mains shall be extended to the subject property, and a public storm
sewer system provided thereon, for the use of all lots and/or building sites in
the development project.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.55 REQUIRED CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   Connection to Existing Storm Sewer. When storm sewer improvements are
required, or proposed, for a subject development project and a portion of
Municipal storm sewer exists upon the subject property, or an adjacent
property, the developer of the current project shall install such enclosed
storm sewer extension as is necessary to connect with the existing Municipal
storm sewer system.
 
   (b)   Connection To New Storm Sewer Main. During the construction of any new
Municipal storm sewer the proper connection thereto of any existing private
storm sewer system or facility within one thousand (1000) feet of the new sewer
main shall be required unless otherwise approved by Council.
      (1)   Said private storm sewer system or facility shall be repaired and/
or restored as is necessary, in the opinion of the Municipal Engineer, to
conform with minimum acceptable engineering standards prior to its connection
to the Municipal system. Said repair and/or restoration shall `be at the
property owner's expense.
      (2)   That portion of the private storm sewer system or facility
beginning at, and including, its connection with the Municipal sewer system and
continuing upstream to, and including, the first storm water inlet of the
private system or facility shall be installed, or upgraded as may be necessary
in the opinion of the Municipal Engineer, so as to conform with the then
current Municipal Specifications for Storm Sewers. Said installation and/or
upgrade shall be at the property owner's expense.
 
   (c)   Roof Drainage Connection to Storm Sewer. Upon any property, premises,
building site, or within any subdivision or planned unit development, where
storm water management facilities have been constructed pursuant to the
requirements of Codified Ordinance Chapter
1153 , all building roof drainage down spouts and/or roof drains shall be
connected to the storm water management facilities. The point of said
connection and method of connection shall be subject to the approval of the
Municipal Engineer.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Ord. 1926. Passed 7-8-99.)
 
929.56 PROVIDE FOR FUTURE CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   In major subdivisions and PUD's the developer shall make such
provisions for the future connection of private storm sewers from building
sites and properties, contained within the subject development, so as to
prevent the need to cut, or bore under, the street pavement in order to make
said future connections. The developer shall further make such provisions for
the connection of future storm sewers from adjacent undeveloped lands as may
reasonably be required by the Approving Authority in accordance with accepted
engineering practice, design and standards. Said provisions shall be as herein
after required, or such other provisions achieving the same intent and effect
as may be approved by the Municipal Approving Authority.
      (1)   In Planned Unit Developments and Major Subdivisions, which include
commercial and/or industrial building sites, the developer shall provide and
install stubbed service laterals for each multifamily1 commercial and
industrial building site when the future installation thereof will require
cutting, or boring under, the street pavement. Stubbed laterals to serve one
and two family lots or building sites are not required except when, in the
opinion of the Municipal Engineer, the particular circumstances of a lot or
building site necessitate a storm sewer inlet thereon. The connection shall be
made and the service lateral installed to the right of way line of the proposed
street (or a minimum of fifteen (15) feet beyond the edge of pavement adjacent
to the building site to be served). The terminus of the lateral shall be capped
and its location marked with a wood pole or other device approved by the
Authority Having Jurisdiction. When storm sewers are not provided in, or
adjacent to, the street, the lateral, if required to satisfy the noted
condition, shall be installed to a point approved by the Approving Authority.
      (2)   When, in the opinion of the Municipal Approving Authority and the
Municipal Engineer, the topography on adjacent undeveloped land is such that
future storm sewers thereon are best drained by connection to the sewers on the
subject property, then the developer of the current project shall make such
provisions as are required by the Approving Authority for the connection of
future storm sewers from adjacent undeveloped lands. Said developer shall grant
a right of way or easement, conforming to these regulations, for said future
connection. The right of way or easement shall begin at an existing or proposed
storm sewer manhole located within the subject project boundaries, and outside
of any street pavement, and shall continue to the property line of said
adjacent land. Said right of way, or easement, shall be subject to the approval
of the Approving Authority in all respects including but not limited to;
location, route, point of connection within the subject development storm
sewer, and point of intersection with the adjacent property line.
         (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.57 STREET OPENING AND BORING.
   Any street opening or boring, and the restoration thereof, shall be in
accordance with the requirements for same as set forth in Chapter
901  (Street Regulations).
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.58 PROPER CONNECTION REQUIRED.
   Any connection to the Municipal storm sewer system shall be in strict
conformance with this regulation and other applicable regulations and standards
of the Municipality.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.59 ENCLOSED STORM SEWER SYSTEM.
   The developer shall design and construct an enclosed storm sewer system for
all proposed development projects. The proposed system shall provide for the
proper drainage of storm water from the development project, and each lot or
building site as may be contained therein. When, in the opinion of the
Municipal Engineer, the proposed system is inadequate for the site conditions
or municipal design standards, then the Approving Authority may require that
additional improvements be designed and constructed by the developer to meet
the requirements of the Municipal Ordinances and other related municipal
standards, specifications, regulations and requirements.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91; Am. Ord. 1926. Passed 7-8-99.)
   (a)   When enclosed Municipal storm sewers do not exist along the existing
public street, or streets, providing access to the subject property the
developer shall be required to install, and dedicate to public use, an enclosed
storm sewer. The required storm sewer shall be installed within the right-of-
way or easement for said street; on the same side of the street as the subject
project and between the property lines of the subject property. The design
criteria and installation shall conform to Section
929.61 (Public Storm Sewers). A manhole inlet shall be provided within the
right of way at the upstream end, or ends, of said enclosed storm sewer. The
point of discharge and improvements required therefor shall, at a minimum, be
in accordance with Section
929.60 (Storm Sewer Outfalls).
      (Ord. 1378. Passed 05-14-92.)
   (b)   The developer may be required by the Municipal Approving Authority to
deed lands in fee simple, or grant an easement to the Municipality, for any
storm water drainage improvements (see Sections
929.52 (Dedication to Public Use) and
929.33 (Easements And Rights Of Way)).
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.60 STORM SEWER OUTFALLS.
   When a proposed storm sewer does not discharge into an enclosed municipal
storm sewer, the point of discharge shall conform to the requirements set forth
herein. The developer shall provide and install headwall, erosion control and
other associated and necessary improvements required by the Municipal Approving
Authority, at the approved point of discharge in accordance with the standards
set forth in Section
929.31 (Design Standards).
   (a)   Where a water course or drainage way that is not designated by the
Municipal Master Storm Drainage Plan as a receiving waterway, exists upon a
subject development property, private storm sewers required on said property
may be discharged within said water course or drainage way when approved by the
Municipal Approving Authority.
   (b)   Where a drainage way that is designated by the Municipal Storm Water
Drainage Plan as a receiving waterway exists upon a subject development
property the proposed storm sewer may discharge within the required easement
for said waterway. Further the Approving Authority may require that the
proposed storm sewer, or a portion thereof, be dedicated to public use for the
purpose of connecting the Municipal storm sewer system to said receiving
waterway. The subject storm sewer, or designated portion thereof, shall conform
to Section
929.61 (Public Storm Sewers).
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.61 PUBLIC STORM SEWERS.
   When storm sewers are required to be installed and dedicated to public use
they shall further conform to the following requirements:
   (a)   The proposed sewer shall be enclosed.
   (b)   Easements or rights of way shall be required.
   (c)   The proposed storm sewer system shall have a design capacity capable
of serving the drainage area of which it is a part and the drainage area of any
part of the existing municipal system which may be connected thereto.
   (d)   The developer shall provide for the connection of other existing or
future storm sewers at such points upon the subject development property, or in
the public right of way immediately adjacent thereto, as may be reasonably
required by the Approving Authority.
   (e)   When the storm sewer is not connected to an enclosed municipal storm
sewer the point of discharge shall conform to the requirements of Section
929.60 (Storm Sewer Outfalls).
   (f)   The developer shall not be required to pay for construction costs
associated with design standards which are in excess of those required for the
subject development project. Such additional costs may be assessed by Council
to all benefited property owners in accordance with the procedures for same as
provided for by law.
      (Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.70 SEWER SYSTEM OPERATION.
 
929.71 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Authority having jurisdiction, or his duly authorized agent, shall have
access at all reasonable hours to any property having Municipal storm sewers
thereon for the purpose of making necessary examinations and/or repairs.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.72 SYSTEM DAMAGE AND TAMPERING.
   No person shall injure, break, remove, obstruct, restrict, divert or
otherwise damage or tamper with any manhole, inlet, cover, pipe or any other
part of any Municipal sewer except for the purpose of making repairs,
connection, or other authorized work in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.73 SERVICE OUTSIDE MUNICIPALITY.
   Storm sewer connections, trunk lines, and any other storm sewer services
shall not be provided, extended or furnished to any person, corporation or any
other entity, if the location of the service is beyond the municipal
corporation limits. Present users of the municipal storm sewer system, located
outside of the municipal corporation limit, are exempt from this section.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.74 PROHIBITED CONNECTIONS.
   (a)   Storm water discharge into any sanitary sewer shall be prohibited (see
Chapter
925  (Sanitary Sewer Regulations))
 
   (b)   The discharge of sanitary sewerage, or any industrial waste, into any
storm sewer is prohibited. No person shall connect any cesspool, privy vault or
any other type of sanitary discharge, with any Municipal or private storm
sewer.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.75 ABANDONMENT OF SERVICE.
   At any time a storm sewer user connection is to be abandon, the connection
shall be excavated at the point of tap-in; the service lateral shall be
disconnected in a manner approved by the Municipal inspector; and the tap
connection shall be tightly and permanently capped. Inspection of such work
shall be required under the provisions of Section
929.93 (Construction Inspection and Testing) prior to backfilling the
excavation.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
 
929.76 PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES.
   No person shall put, throw, discharge or permit into any storm sewer or
connection thereto any heavy substance, rags, waste, clothes, garbage, gasoline
waste from garages, gasoline, sand, gravel, marble or emery dust, cinders,
ashes, sticks or any other substance or material that might settle in or clog
such storm sewer or connection, or create a hazard.
(Ord. 1327. Passed 5-9-91.)
